verses.text: In the beginning was the Logos, and the Logos was with God, and the Logos was God.
This one was in the beginning with God.
All things came into being through him, and apart from him not one thing came into being that has come into being.
In him was life, and the life was the light of humanity.
And the light shines in the darkness, and the darkness did not grasp it.
There came a man sent from God, whose name was John.
This one came as a witness, in order to testify about the light, so that all might believe through him.
He himself was not the light, but came to testify about the light.
The true light, which enlightens every person, was coming into the world.
He was in the world, and the world came into being through him, and the world did not know him.
He came into his own domain, and his own people did not receive him.
But to as many as did receive him, he gave authority to become children of God—to those who trust in his name,
who were born not from bloods, nor from the will of the flesh, nor from the will of a man, but from God.
And the Logos became flesh and pitched his tent among us, and we beheld his glory—glory as of a uniquely-born one from the Father, full of grace and truth.
(John testifies about him and has cried out, saying, "This was the one about whom I said, 'The one coming after me has taken precedence over me, because he existed before me.'")
For from his fullness we have all received, even grace in place of grace.
For the Law was given through Moses; grace and truth came into being through Jesus Christ.
No one has ever seen God. The uniquely-born one, himself God, the one who is in the bosom of the Father—that one has made him known.
And this is John's testimony when the Judeans sent priests and Levites from Jerusalem to ask him, "Who are you?"
And he confessed and did not deny—he confessed, "I am not the Messiah."
And they asked him, "What then? Are you Elijah?" And he says, "I am not." "Are you the Prophet?" And he answered, "No."
So they said to him, "Who are you? So that we may give an answer to those who sent us. What do you say about yourself?"
He said, "I am the voice of one crying out in the wilderness: 'Make straight the way of the Lord,' just as Isaiah the prophet said."
Now they had been sent from among the Pharisees.
And they questioned him and said to him, "Why then do you baptize if you are not the Messiah, nor Elijah, nor the Prophet?"
John answered them, saying, "I baptize in water. In your midst stands one whom you do not know,
the one coming after me, of whom I am not worthy to untie the strap of his sandal."
These things happened in Bethany across the Jordan, where John was baptizing.
The next day he sees Jesus coming toward him, and he says, "Look—the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world!
This is the one about whom I said, 'After me comes a man who has taken precedence over me, because he existed before me.'
And I did not know him, but so that he might be revealed to Israel—for this reason I came baptizing in water."
And John testified, saying, "I have seen the Spirit descending like a dove from heaven, and it remained upon him.

And I did not know him, but the one who sent me to baptize in water—that one said to me, 'The one upon whom you see the Spirit descending and remaining upon him, this is the one who baptizes in the Holy Spirit.'
And I have seen and have testified that this is the Chosen One of God."
The next day, John was standing again with two of his disciples,
and watching Jesus as he walked by, he says, "Look—the Lamb of God!"
And the two disciples heard him speaking and followed Jesus.
But Jesus turned and, seeing them following, says to them, "What are you seeking?" They said to him, "Rabbi" (which translated means Teacher), "where are you staying?"
He says to them, "Come and you will see." So they came and saw where he was staying, and they remained with him that day. It was about the tenth hour.
Andrew, the brother of Simon Peter, was one of the two who heard this from John and followed him.
This one first finds his own brother Simon and says to him, "We have found the Messiah" (which is translated Christ).
He led him to Jesus. Looking intently at him, Jesus said, "You are Simon, son of John. You will be called Cephas" (which is translated Peter).
The next day he decided to go out to Galilee. And he finds Philip and says to him, Jesus does, "Follow me."
Now Philip was from Bethsaida, from the city of Andrew and Peter.
Philip finds Nathanael and says to him, "We have found the one about whom Moses wrote in the Law, and the prophets also—Jesus, son of Joseph, from Nazareth."
And Nathanael said to him, "Can anything good come out of Nazareth?" Philip says to him, "Come and see."
Jesus saw Nathanael coming toward him and says about him, "Look—truly an Israelite in whom there is no deceit!"
Nathanael says to him, "From where do you know me?" Jesus answered and said to him, "Before Philip called you, when you were under the fig tree, I saw you."
Nathanael answered him, "Rabbi, you are the Son of God! You are the King of Israel!"
Jesus answered and said to him, "Because I told you that I saw you under the fig tree, you believe? You will see greater things than these."
And he says to him, "Amen, amen, I tell you all: you will see heaven opened and the angels of God ascending and descending upon the Son of Man."

chapters.notes:
**"Logos" (vv. 1, 14)**: The Greek term is retained rather than translating it as "Word." For Greek readers, *logos* carried profound philosophical freight: the divine rational principle ordering the cosmos (Heraclitus, Stoicism), God's creative speech in Genesis, personified Wisdom in Proverbs 8, and Philo's intermediary between God and creation. No single English word captures this range. Like "Christ" or "baptize," it functions better as a loanword that invites reflection on its rich meaning.

**"Did not grasp it" (v. 5)**: The Greek *katelaben* can mean either "comprehend/understand" or "seize/overcome." The ambiguity is likely intentional. The darkness both failed to understand the light and failed to extinguish it.

**"Pitched his tent" (v. 14)**: The Greek *eskēnōsen* literally means "dwelt in a tent/tabernacle." This evokes the Tabernacle where God's glory dwelt among Israel in the wilderness (Exodus 40:34-35). The standard "dwelt" loses this resonance.

**"Uniquely-born one" (vv. 14, 18)**: The Greek *monogenēs* means "only one of its kind" or "unique," not necessarily "only-begotten" (which would be *monogennētos*). It emphasizes the unique relationship and nature, not merely biological generation.

**"Bloods" (v. 13)**: The Greek *haimatōn* is plural—"bloods." This may refer to the Jewish teaching that a child's blood came from both parents' bloodlines, emphasizing that divine birth has nothing to do with human ancestry or procreation.

**"Grace in place of grace" (v. 16)**: The Greek *charin anti charitos* uses *anti*, which typically means "in place of" or "instead of," suggesting successive waves of grace or one gracious dispensation replacing another, rather than simply "grace upon grace."

**"The Judeans" (v. 19)**: The Greek *hoi Ioudaioi* means "the Judeans"—referring either to people from Judea specifically or, by extension, to the religious authorities in Jerusalem. The term "Jews" is anachronistic and misleading for a first-century context where all the participants are ethnically and religiously Jewish.

**"The Prophet" (vv. 21, 25)**: With the definite article, this refers to the prophet like Moses promised in Deuteronomy 18:15-18, expected in first-century Jewish eschatology.

**"Chosen One" (v. 34)**: While some manuscripts read "Son," the better-attested reading is *eklektos* ("chosen" or "elect"), which echoes Isaiah's Servant (Isaiah 42:1).

**"The tenth hour" (v. 39)**: About 4 p.m. if counting from sunrise (6 a.m.), or 10 a.m. if using Roman time from midnight. The former is more likely in Jewish Palestinian context.

**"Son of Man" (v. 51)**: This phrase (*ho huios tou anthrōpou*) evokes both the human figure in Daniel 7:13-14 who receives divine authority, and may also carry the Aramaic idiom where *bar nasha* can mean simply "a human being" or "this person." Jesus's usage makes it a title of eschatological authority.

verses.text: On the third day a wedding took place in Cana of Galilee, and the mother of Jesus was there.
Jesus too was invited, along with his disciples, to the wedding.
When the wine ran short, the mother of Jesus said to him, "They have no wine."
Jesus said to her, "What is that to me and to you, woman? My hour has not yet come."
His mother said to the servants, "Do whatever he tells you."
Now standing there were six stone water jars, set out for the purification practices of the Judeans, each holding twenty to thirty gallons.
Jesus said to them, "Fill the jars with water." So they filled them to the brim.
Then he said to them, "Now draw some out and take it to the master of the feast." And they took it.
When the master of the feast tasted the water that had become wine—he did not know where it came from, though the servants who had drawn the water knew—the master of the feast called the bridegroom
and said to him, "Everyone serves the good wine first, and when people have drunk freely, then the inferior wine. But you have kept the good wine until now."
This, in Cana of Galilee, Jesus did as the beginning of the signs, and he revealed his glory, and his disciples believed in him.
After this he went down to Capernaum—he and his mother and his brothers and his disciples—and they remained there not many days.
The Passover of the Judeans was near, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
In the temple he found those selling oxen and sheep and doves, and the money-changers seated at their tables.
Making a whip out of cords, he drove them all out of the temple, both the sheep and the oxen, and he poured out the coins of the money-changers and overturned their tables.
To those selling doves he said, "Take these things out of here! Stop making my Father's house a house of trade!"
His disciples remembered that it is written: "Zeal for your house will consume me."
So the Judeans responded and said to him, "What sign do you show us, since you are doing these things?"
Jesus answered and said to them, "Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up."
The Judeans then said, "This temple was built over forty-six years, and you will raise it up in three days?"
But he was speaking about the temple of his body.
Therefore, when he was raised from the dead, his disciples remembered that he had said this, and they believed the scripture and the word that Jesus had spoken.
Now while he was in Jerusalem during the Passover, during the feast, many believed in his name when they saw the signs he was doing.
But Jesus himself did not entrust himself to them, because he knew all people
and because he had no need for anyone to testify about humanity, for he himself knew what was in a human being.

chapters.notes:
**"What is that to me and to you" (v. 4)**: The Greek phrase τί ἐμοὶ καὶ σοί is a Semitic idiom that appears throughout the LXX and the Gospels. It establishes distance or questions relevance: "What do we have in common in this matter?" The traditional "What does this have to do with me?" loses the relational aspect. This rendering preserves both the strangeness and the sense of Jesus questioning the shared concern.

**"Woman" (v. 4)**: The Greek γύναι is not disrespectful in Greek (it can be used affectionately), but it is formal and creates distance. Jesus is establishing a boundary between familial obligation and his messianic mission. Translating it as "Mother" would obscure this distancing function.

**"My hour" (v. 4)**: In John's Gospel, ἡ ὥρα μου is a technical term referring to Jesus's appointed time of glorification through death and resurrection. The first-century audience attuned to John's theology would recognize this as more than a simple temporal reference.

**"Judeans" (throughout)**: The Greek Ἰουδαῖοι is complex in John's Gospel. It can mean ethnic Jews, residents of Judea, or (often in John) the religious authorities opposed to Jesus. Here I've used "Judeans" to preserve the ambiguity of the Greek—sometimes it clearly means the religious establishment (v. 18, 20), and sometimes it's more neutral (v. 6, 13, referring to purification customs and the Passover festival). The term creates a literary pattern in John that "Jews" in modern English cannot preserve without triggering anachronistic associations.

**"Purification practices" (v. 6)**: The phrase κατὰ τὸν καθαρισμὸν refers to the ritual washing practices prescribed in Torah and elaborated in Second Temple tradition. "Purification rites" would work, but "practices" feels less stilted in contemporary English while maintaining accuracy.

**"Master of the feast" (v. 8-10)**: The Greek ἀρχιτρίκλινος is a compound meaning "chief of the dining couches"—the person responsible for managing the banquet, including wine service. "Master of the feast" captures both the authority and the festive context better than "steward" or "headwaiter."

**"Drunk freely" (v. 10)**: The Greek μεθυσθῶσιν is from μεθύω, meaning to become drunk or intoxicated. The traditional euphemism "well drunk" is archaic. "Drunk freely" conveys that guests have drunk to satisfaction without being prudish about wine consumption.

**"Signs" (v. 11, 18, 23)**: The Greek σημεῖον is John's preferred term for Jesus's miracles. Unlike the Synoptics' δύναμις ("mighty work" or "power"), σημεῖον emphasizes that these acts point beyond themselves to Jesus's identity. The first-century reader would understand these as revelatory acts, not mere wonders. "Signs" preserves this precisely.

**"Revealed his glory" (v. 11)**: The verb ἐφανέρωσεν (made manifest/visible) with δόξαν (glory) evokes the Exodus tradition where God's glory was made visible to Israel. John's audience would catch this echo.

**"House of trade" (v. 16)**: The Greek οἶκον ἐμπορίου means a commercial establishment, a place of business. Jesus is not objecting to the temple having a marketplace function per se (which was necessary for sacrifices), but to the temple being turned into a business operation. "House of trade" preserves the wordplay with "house" (οἶκον) that would be lost with "marketplace."

**"Zeal for your house will consume me" (v. 17)**: This quotes Psalm 69:9 (LXX 68:10). The verb καταφάγεταί is future tense—"will consume"—which in the context of John's narrative points forward to Jesus's passion. The disciples remember this after the resurrection (v. 22), understanding it prophetically.

**"Did not entrust himself" (v. 24)**: The Greek οὐκ ἐπίστευεν αὑτὸν αὐτοῖς creates a wordplay with πιστεύω that appears in v. 23 ("many believed") and v. 24 ("Jesus did not believe/entrust"). The same verb means both "to believe in" and "to entrust to." While they believed in him, he did not entrust himself to them. This reciprocal dynamic is crucial to preserve.

verses.text: Now there was a man from among the Pharisees, Nicodemus by name, a ruler of the Jews.
This man came to him at night and said to him, "Rabbi, we know that you have come from God as a teacher, for no one can do these signs that you are doing unless God is with him."
Jesus answered and said to him, "Truly, truly, I tell you, unless someone is born from above, he cannot see the kingdom of God."
Nicodemus said to him, "How can a person be born when he is old? Surely he cannot enter into his mother's womb a second time and be born, can he?"
Jesus answered, "Truly, truly, I tell you, unless someone is born of water and Spirit, he cannot enter into the kingdom of God.
What has been born from the flesh is flesh, and what has been born from the Spirit is spirit.
Do not be astonished that I said to you, 'You must be born from above.'
The wind blows where it wills, and you hear its sound, but you do not know where it comes from or where it is going. So it is with everyone who has been born of the Spirit."
Nicodemus answered and said to him, "How can these things happen?"
Jesus answered and said to him, "You are the teacher of Israel and you do not understand these things?
Truly, truly, I tell you, we speak what we know and we bear witness to what we have seen, yet you people do not accept our testimony.
If I have told you about earthly things and you do not believe, how will you believe if I tell you about heavenly things?
And no one has ascended into heaven except the one who descended from heaven—the Son of Humanity.
And just as Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, so must the Son of Humanity be lifted up,
so that everyone who believes in him may have eternal life.
For God loved the world in this way: he gave his only Son, so that everyone who believes in him should not perish but have eternal life.
For God did not send his Son into the world to condemn the world, but so that the world might be saved through him.
The one who believes in him is not condemned, but the one who does not believe has already been condemned, because he has not believed in the name of the only Son of God.
And this is the judgment: that the light has come into the world, and people loved the darkness rather than the light, for their deeds were evil.
For everyone who does worthless things hates the light and does not come to the light, so that his deeds may not be exposed.
But the one who does the truth comes to the light, so that his deeds may be made visible—that they have been worked in God."
After these things, Jesus and his disciples came into the land of Judea, and there he spent time with them and was baptizing.
Now John also was baptizing at Aenon near Salim, because there was an abundance of water there, and people kept coming and being baptized—
for John had not yet been thrown into prison.
Then a dispute arose on the part of John's disciples with a Judean about purification.
And they came to John and said to him, "Rabbi, the one who was with you across the Jordan, to whom you have borne witness—look, he is baptizing and everyone is going to him."
John answered and said, "A person cannot receive even one thing unless it has been given to him from heaven.
You yourselves bear witness for me that I said, 'I am not the Christ, but rather I have been sent ahead of him.'
The one who has the bride is the bridegroom. But the friend of the bridegroom, who stands and listens for him, rejoices greatly at the bridegroom's voice. So this joy of mine has been fulfilled.
He must increase, but I must decrease.
The one who comes from above is above all. The one who is from the earth is of the earth and speaks of the earth. The one who comes from heaven is above all.
What he has seen and heard, this he testifies to, yet no one accepts his testimony.
The one who has accepted his testimony has certified that God is true.
For the one whom God has sent speaks the words of God, for he does not give the Spirit by measure.
The Father loves the Son and has given all things into his hand.
The one who believes in the Son has eternal life, but the one who disobeys the Son will not see life—rather, the wrath of God remains upon him."

chapters.notes:
**"Born from above" (vv. 3, 7)**: The Greek ἄνωθεν carries a deliberate double meaning: "from above" (spatially/theologically) and "again" (temporally). Nicodemus takes it in the second sense (v. 4), but Jesus clearly intends the first. The wordplay is essential to the dialogue. "From above" preserves Jesus's intended meaning while allowing readers to understand Nicodemus's confusion.

**"Son of Humanity" (vv. 13, 14)**: The Greek ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου literally means "the son of the human" or "the son of humanity." This is Jesus's preferred self-designation, evoking Daniel 7:13-14 where "one like a son of man" receives eternal dominion. The traditional "Son of Man" obscures this, as it sounds like a mere synonym for "human being" in modern English. "Son of Humanity" better conveys both the human dimension and the corporate/representative nature of the figure.

**"Wind/Spirit" (v. 8)**: The Greek πνεῦμα means both "wind" and "spirit." The verse exploits this double meaning: "The πνεῦμα blows where it wills... so it is with everyone born of the πνεῦμα." I have used "wind" and "Spirit" to make the analogy clear in English, though the original's wordplay is untranslatable.

**"Only Son" (vv. 16, 18)**: The Greek μονογενής means "only" or "unique," not "only-begotten" (a later theological reading). It emphasizes the Son's singular status, not his mode of generation.

**"Worthless things" (v. 20)**: The Greek φαῦλα means cheap, worthless, or base—not merely "evil" but things of no value. It contrasts with "doing the truth" in v. 21.

**"Does the truth" (v. 21)**: The Greek ποιῶν τὴν ἀλήθειαν is a Hebraic idiom meaning to act truthfully, to live according to truth—not merely to "practice" truth in some abstract sense. "Does the truth" preserves the concrete, active sense.

**Singular vs. plural shifts**: Jesus shifts between singular "you" (Nicodemus) and plural "you" (addressing a broader audience) in vv. 7, 11-12. This is preserved in the translation where English allows clarification ("you people" in v. 11).

**"A Judean" (v. 25)**: The Greek Ἰουδαίου is singular, indicating one individual, though some manuscripts have the plural. The singular reading is better attested.

**"Disobeys" (v. 36)**: The Greek ἀπειθῶν means "refuses to be persuaded, disobeys, is disobedient"—not merely intellectual disbelief but active resistance. This contrasts with the believing/trusting (πιστεύων) of the first part of the verse.

verses.text: When Jesus learned that the Pharisees had heard that Jesus was making and baptizing more disciples than John
—although Jesus himself was not baptizing, but his disciples were—
he left Judea and went back again to Galilee.
Now he had to pass through Samaria.
So he comes to a Samaritan town called Sychar, near the piece of land that Jacob gave to his son Joseph.
Jacob's well was there. Jesus, exhausted from the journey, sat down just as he was by the well. It was about the sixth hour.
A woman from Samaria comes to draw water. Jesus says to her, "Give me a drink."
(For his disciples had gone off into the town to buy food.)
So the Samaritan woman says to him, "How is it that you, being a Jew, ask for a drink from me, a Samaritan woman?" (For Jews do not associate with Samaritans.)
Jesus answered and said to her, "If you knew the gift of God, and who it is that is saying to you, 'Give me a drink,' you would have asked him, and he would have given you living water."
The woman says to him, "Sir, you have no bucket and the well is deep. Where then do you get this living water?
You aren't greater than our father Jacob, are you?—who gave us the well and drank from it himself, along with his sons and his livestock."
Jesus answered and said to her, "Everyone who drinks from this water will thirst again.
But whoever drinks from the water that I will give him will never thirst for all eternity. Rather, the water that I will give him will become in him a spring of water leaping up into eternal life."
The woman says to him, "Sir, give me this water, so that I won't be thirsty or have to keep coming here to draw."
He says to her, "Go, call your husband and come back here."
The woman answered and said to him, "I don't have a husband." Jesus says to her, "You've spoken well in saying, 'I don't have a husband.'
For you've had five husbands, and the one you now have is not your husband. This you've spoken truthfully."
The woman says to him, "Sir, I perceive that you are a prophet.
Our fathers worshiped on this mountain, yet you people say that in Jerusalem is the place where one must worship."
Jesus says to her, "Believe me, woman, an hour is coming when neither on this mountain nor in Jerusalem will you worship the Father.
You worship what you do not know; we worship what we know, because salvation is from the Jews.
But an hour is coming—and is now here—when the true worshipers will worship the Father in spirit and truth, for indeed the Father seeks such people as his worshipers.
God is spirit, and those who worship him must worship in spirit and truth."
The woman says to him, "I know that Messiah is coming"—the one called Christ—"when that one comes, he will proclaim all things to us."
Jesus says to her, "I am—the one speaking to you."
And at this point his disciples came, and they were astonished that he was speaking with a woman. Yet no one said, "What are you seeking?" or "Why are you talking with her?"
So the woman left her water jar and went off into the town and says to the people,
"Come, see a man who told me everything I ever did. Could this be the Christ?"
They went out from the town and were making their way toward him.
In the meantime, the disciples were urging him, saying, "Rabbi, eat."
But he said to them, "I have food to eat that you don't know about."
So the disciples were saying to one another, "No one brought him something to eat, did they?"
Jesus says to them, "My food is to do the will of the one who sent me and to complete his work.
Don't you say, 'There are still four months, and then the harvest comes'? Look, I tell you: lift up your eyes and see the fields—they are white, ready for harvest! Already
the reaper is receiving wages and gathering fruit for eternal life, so that the sower and the reaper may rejoice together.
For in this the saying is true: 'One sows and another reaps.'
I sent you to reap that for which you haven't labored; others have labored, and you have entered into their labor."
Now many Samaritans from that town believed in him because of the woman's testimony: "He told me everything I did."
So when the Samaritans came to him, they asked him to stay with them, and he stayed there two days.
And many more believed because of his message,
and they were saying to the woman, "We no longer believe just because of your account, for we ourselves have heard, and we know that this one truly is the Savior of the world."
After the two days, he went out from there to Galilee.
For Jesus himself had testified that a prophet has no honor in his own homeland.
So when he came into Galilee, the Galileans welcomed him, having seen all that he had done in Jerusalem at the festival, for they too had gone to the festival.
So he came again to Cana of Galilee, where he had made the water wine. And there was a certain royal official whose son was sick in Capernaum.
When this man heard that Jesus had come from Judea into Galilee, he went to him and was asking him to come down and heal his son, for he was about to die.
So Jesus said to him, "Unless you people see signs and wonders, you will never believe."
The royal official says to him, "Sir, come down before my child dies."
Jesus says to him, "Go; your son lives." The man believed the word that Jesus spoke to him and set out.
Already as he was going down, his servants met him, saying that his boy was living.
So he inquired from them the hour at which he got better. They said to him, "Yesterday at the seventh hour the fever left him."
So the father knew that it was at that very hour in which Jesus had said to him, "Your son lives," and he believed, along with his entire household.
Now this again was a second sign that Jesus performed after coming from Judea into Galilee.

chapters.notes:
**"Had to pass through Samaria" (v. 4)**: The Greek ἔδει carries a sense of divine necessity or compulsion, not merely geographical necessity (Jews often avoided Samaria by crossing the Jordan). This suggests theological purpose.

**"Just as he was" (v. 6)**: The phrase οὕτως here conveys Jesus sitting down in an informal, natural way—exhausted, without ceremony.

**"Sixth hour" (v. 6)**: In John's reckoning (following Roman timekeeping), this is approximately noon, the hottest part of the day—an unusual time for drawing water, which was typically done in morning or evening.

**"Living water" (vv. 10-11)**: The Greek ὕδωρ ζῶν can mean both "running water" (fresh, flowing water from a spring, as opposed to cistern water) and "life-giving water." The woman initially understands the former; Jesus means the latter. The wordplay is intentional and preserved.

**"Associate with" (v. 9)**: The verb συγχρῶνται means to use things in common or to have dealings with. The statement reflects the social and religious barrier between Jews and Samaritans.

**"I am" (v. 26)**: The Greek Ἐγώ εἰμι can be simply "I am [he]" (identifying himself as Messiah) or can echo the divine name from Exodus 3:14. John frequently uses this phrase with theological weight. The ambiguity is likely intentional.

**"In spirit and truth" (vv. 23-24)**: The Greek ἐν πνεύματι καὶ ἀληθείᾳ likely means "in [the realm of] Spirit and [the realm of] truth"—worship that is spiritual (not tied to physical location) and genuine (not false). The anarthrous construction (no articles before "spirit" and "truth") suggests these are spheres or modes of worship.

**"God is spirit" (v. 24)**: The Greek πνεῦμα ὁ θεός is a qualitative statement about God's nature—God is of the order of spirit, not material. This explains why worship is no longer tied to physical locations.

**"Everything I ever did" (v. 29, 39)**: Literally "all things which I did," but the context and the woman's amazement suggest the comprehensive sense of her past being known.

**"Royal official" (v. 46)**: The Greek βασιλικός means one in service to the king (Herod Antipas)—a government official or courtier, not necessarily nobility himself.

**"White, ready for harvest" (v. 35)**: The fields are λευκαί ("white"), describing grain ready to harvest. This may also be a visual reference to the Samaritans in white garments approaching (v. 30), whom Jesus sees as a spiritual harvest.

**"Savior of the world" (v. 42)**: This title ὁ σωτὴρ τοῦ κόσμου was used of Roman emperors and pagan deities. Its application to Jesus by Samaritans (outsiders to Judaism) emphasizes the universal scope of his mission.

verses.text: After these things there was a festival of the Jews, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
Now there is in Jerusalem, by the Sheep Gate, a pool called in Hebrew Bethesda, which has five colonnades.
In these colonnades lay a crowd of people who were sick—blind, lame, and paralyzed.
A certain man was there who had been in his sickness for thirty-eight years.
When Jesus saw him lying there and knew that he had already been in this condition for a long time, he said to him, "Do you want to become well?"
The sick man answered him, "Sir, I have no one to put me into the pool when the water is stirred up. While I am trying to get there, someone else goes down ahead of me."
Jesus said to him, "Get up, pick up your mat, and walk."
And immediately the man became well, and he picked up his mat and began to walk. Now that day was a Sabbath.
So the Jewish authorities said to the man who had been healed, "It is the Sabbath, and it is not lawful for you to carry your mat."
But he answered them, "The one who made me well—that man said to me, 'Pick up your mat and walk.'"
They asked him, "Who is this man who told you, 'Pick up your mat and walk'?"
But the one who had been healed did not know who it was, for Jesus had slipped away, since there was a crowd in the place.
After these things Jesus found him in the temple and said to him, "Look, you have become well. Stop sinning, so that nothing worse happens to you."
The man went away and reported to the Jewish authorities that it was Jesus who had made him well.
And because of this the Jewish authorities began persecuting Jesus, because he was doing these things on the Sabbath.
But Jesus answered them, "My Father is working until now, and I myself am working."

Because of this, therefore, the Jewish authorities were seeking all the more to kill him, because not only was he breaking the Sabbath, but he was also calling God his own Father, making himself equal with God.

So Jesus responded and began saying to them, "Amen, amen, I tell you, the Son can do nothing on his own initiative, but only what he sees the Father doing. For whatever that one does, these things the Son likewise does.
For the Father loves the Son and shows him everything that he himself is doing, and he will show him greater works than these, so that you may be amazed.
For just as the Father raises the dead and gives them life, so also the Son gives life to whomever he wishes.
For the Father judges no one, but has given all judgment to the Son,
so that all may honor the Son just as they honor the Father. The one who does not honor the Son does not honor the Father who sent him.
Amen, amen, I tell you that the one who hears my word and trusts in the one who sent me has eternal life, and does not come into judgment but has passed over from death into life.
Amen, amen, I tell you that an hour is coming—and now is—when the dead will hear the voice of the Son of God, and those who hear will live.
For just as the Father has life in himself, so he has also granted the Son to have life in himself.
And he has given him authority to execute judgment, because he is the Son of Man.
Do not be amazed at this, because an hour is coming in which all who are in the tombs will hear his voice
and will come out—those who have done good things to a resurrection of life, and those who have practiced worthless things to a resurrection of judgment.
I can do nothing on my own initiative. Just as I hear, I judge, and my judgment is just, because I do not seek my own will but the will of the one who sent me.
If I testify about myself, my testimony is not valid.
There is another who testifies about me, and I know that the testimony he gives about me is valid.
You have sent messengers to John, and he has testified to the truth.
Now I do not receive testimony from a human being, but I say these things so that you may be saved.
That man was the lamp that burns and shines, and you were willing to celebrate for an hour in his light.
But I have testimony greater than John's. For the works that the Father has given me to complete—these very works that I am doing—testify about me that the Father has sent me.
And the Father who sent me—that one has testified about me. You have never heard his voice, nor have you seen his form,
and you do not have his word remaining in you, because you do not trust in the one whom that one sent.
You search the scriptures because you think that in them you possess eternal life. Yet these are the very ones that testify about me,
and you refuse to come to me so that you may have life.
I do not receive glory from human beings,
but I have come to know you—that you do not have the love of God in yourselves.
I have come in my Father's name, and you do not receive me. If another comes in his own name, you will receive that one.
How can you trust, when you receive glory from one another and do not seek the glory that comes from the only God?
Do not suppose that I will accuse you before the Father. There is one who accuses you: Moses, in whom you have placed your hope.
For if you trusted Moses, you would trust me, because that man wrote about me.
But if you do not trust his writings, how will you trust my words?"

chapters.notes:
**"Jewish authorities" (vv. 10, 15, 16, 18)**: The phrase οἱ Ἰουδαῖοι in John's Gospel is context-dependent. Here it clearly refers not to Jewish people generally (Jesus and his followers were Jewish), but to the religious leadership in Jerusalem who opposed Jesus. "The Jews" in English misleadingly suggests ethnic or religious antagonism rather than a specific power structure. "Jewish authorities" captures the institutional nature of the opposition.

**"Amen, amen"**: Retained rather than translated as "truly, truly" or "verily, verily." This is Jesus's distinctive formula in John (ἀμὴν ἀμὴν), an Aramaic liturgical word meaning "it is reliable, trustworthy." Keeping "Amen" preserves its solemnity and connection to Jewish worship practice.

**"Trusts/trust" rather than "believes"**: The Greek πιστεύω means to place confidence in, to entrust oneself to—more relational and active than English "believe," which can be merely intellectual assent. "Trust" better captures the commitment involved.

**"Son of Man" (v. 27)**: Retained as a title rather than paraphrased. This phrase (υἱὸς ἀνθρώπου) evokes Daniel 7:13-14, where "one like a son of man" receives authority and kingdom from the Ancient of Days. First-century Jewish readers would have caught this allusion to divine authority and eschatological judgment.

**"Worthless things" (v. 29)**: The Greek φαῦλα means things of poor quality, base, worthless—not necessarily "evil" in a moral sense but actions lacking value or goodness. This contrasts with τὰ ἀγαθά ("good things").

**"Search/You search" (v. 39)**: The Greek ἐραυνᾶτε is ambiguous—it could be either indicative ("you search") or imperative ("search!"). Context suggests indicative: Jesus is describing their current practice of studying scripture while missing its testimony to him, not commanding them to do something new. This continues the critique begun in v. 38.

**"Celebrate" (v. 35)**: The verb ἀγαλλιάω means to exult, rejoice greatly, celebrate. It's stronger than mere willingness—they were eager to revel in John's ministry, but only "for an hour" (temporarily, superficially).

**"Glory" (vv. 41, 44)**: The Greek δόξα can mean honor, glory, reputation, or praise. In this context, it refers to human acclaim and reputation-seeking versus seeking honor from God. "Glory" preserves the theological weight while encompassing the social dimension.

**"Bethesda" (v. 2)**: The manuscript tradition varies (Bethesda, Bethzatha, Bethsaida), but Bethesda has strong early support and likely reflects the Aramaic בית חסדא (House of Mercy).

**Verse 4 omitted**: Not present in the earliest and best manuscripts. This verse (explaining an angel stirring the water) was a later scribal addition attempting to explain v. 7.

verses.text: After these things, Jesus went away to the far side of the Sea of Galilee (which is the Sea of Tiberias).
A large crowd was following him, because they had been observing the signs he was performing on those who were sick.
Jesus went up the mountain, and there he sat down with his disciples.
Now the Passover, the festival of the Judeans, was near.
So when Jesus lifted up his eyes and saw that a large crowd was coming toward him, he says to Philip, "Where can we buy bread so that these people may eat?"
He was saying this to test him, for he himself knew what he was about to do.
Philip answered him, "Two hundred denarii worth of bread would not be enough for them, so that each one might receive even a little."
One of his disciples, Andrew the brother of Simon Peter, says to him,
"There is a young boy here who has five barley loaves and two small fish—but what are these for so many people?"
Jesus said, "Have the people recline." Now there was abundant grass in the place. So the men reclined, numbering about five thousand.
Then Jesus took the loaves, and after giving thanks, he distributed them to those reclining, and likewise from the fish, as much as they wanted.
When they were satisfied, he says to his disciples, "Gather up the leftover fragments, so that nothing is lost."
So they gathered them up and filled twelve baskets with fragments from the five barley loaves that were left over by those who had eaten.
Therefore when the people saw the sign he had performed, they began saying, "This is truly the Prophet who is coming into the world."
So Jesus, knowing that they were about to come and seize him to make him king, withdrew again to the mountain, alone by himself.
Now when evening came, his disciples went down to the sea,
and after getting into a boat, they began going across the sea toward Capernaum. Darkness had already fallen, and Jesus had not yet come to them.
The sea was being stirred up because a strong wind was blowing.
When they had rowed about three or four miles, they see Jesus walking on the sea and coming near the boat, and they were terrified.
But he says to them, "I AM; do not be afraid."
So they were willing to take him into the boat, and immediately the boat came to be at the land toward which they were going.

On the next day, the crowd standing on the far side of the sea saw that there had been no other boat there except one, and that Jesus had not entered the boat with his disciples, but his disciples had gone away alone.
However, boats from Tiberias came near the place where they had eaten the bread after the Lord gave thanks.
So when the crowd saw that Jesus was not there, nor his disciples, they themselves got into the boats and came to Capernaum seeking Jesus.
And when they found him on the far side of the sea, they said to him, "Rabbi, when did you come here?"
Jesus answered them and said, "Truly, truly I tell you, you are seeking me not because you saw signs but because you ate from the loaves and were filled.
Do not work for the food that perishes, but for the food that endures into eternal life, which the Son of Man will give to you—for the Father, God himself, has set his seal on this one."
So they said to him, "What must we do in order to work the works of God?"
Jesus answered and said to them, "This is the work of God: that you trust in the one whom that one has sent."
So they said to him, "Then what sign are you performing, so that we may see and trust you? What work are you doing?
Our fathers ate the manna in the wilderness, just as it is written: 'He gave them bread from heaven to eat.'"
So Jesus said to them, "Truly, truly I tell you, Moses did not give you the bread from heaven; rather, my Father gives you the true bread from heaven.
For the bread of God is the one who comes down from heaven and gives life to the world."
So they said to him, "Lord, give us this bread always."
Jesus said to them, "I AM the bread of life. The one who comes to me will never hunger, and the one who trusts in me will never, ever thirst.
But I have told you that you have seen me and yet do not trust.
Everything that the Father gives to me will come to me, and the one who comes to me I will certainly not cast out,
because I have come down from heaven not to do my own will but the will of the one who sent me.
And this is the will of the one who sent me: that I should lose nothing of all that he has given me, but should raise it up on the last day.
For this is the will of my Father: that everyone who looks upon the Son and trusts in him should have eternal life, and I will raise him up on the last day."
So the Judeans began grumbling about him because he said, "I AM the bread that came down from heaven,"
and they were saying, "Is this not Jesus the son of Joseph, whose father and mother we know? How does he now say, 'I have come down from heaven'?"
Jesus answered and said to them, "Stop grumbling among yourselves.
No one is able to come to me unless the Father who sent me draws him, and I will raise him up on the last day.
It is written in the Prophets: 'And they will all be taught by God.' Everyone who has heard from the Father and learned comes to me.
Not that anyone has seen the Father except the one who is from God—this one has seen the Father.
Truly, truly I tell you, the one who trusts has eternal life.
I AM the bread of life.
Your fathers ate the manna in the wilderness and died.
This is the bread that comes down from heaven so that anyone may eat from it and not die.
I AM the living bread that came down from heaven. If anyone eats from this bread, he will live forever. And the bread that I will give is my flesh, for the life of the world."
So the Judeans began arguing sharply with one another, saying, "How can this man give us his flesh to eat?"
So Jesus said to them, "Truly, truly I tell you, unless you eat the flesh of the Son of Man and drink his blood, you have no life in yourselves.
The one who feeds on my flesh and drinks my blood has eternal life, and I will raise him up on the last day.
For my flesh is true food, and my blood is true drink.
The one who feeds on my flesh and drinks my blood remains in me, and I in him.
Just as the living Father sent me and I live because of the Father, so also the one who feeds on me—that one will live because of me.
This is the bread that came down from heaven—not like the bread the fathers ate and died. The one who feeds on this bread will live forever."
He said these things while teaching in a synagogue in Capernaum.
Therefore many of his disciples, when they heard this, said, "This word is harsh. Who can listen to it?"
But Jesus, knowing within himself that his disciples were grumbling about this, said to them, "Does this cause you to stumble?
What if you should see the Son of Man ascending to where he was before?
The Spirit is what gives life; the flesh profits nothing. The words that I have spoken to you are spirit and are life.
But there are some among you who do not trust." For Jesus knew from the beginning who those were who did not trust and who it was who would betray him.
And he was saying, "This is why I have told you that no one is able to come to me unless it has been granted to him from the Father."
From this point many of his disciples withdrew to the things behind and no longer walked with him.
So Jesus said to the Twelve, "You don't want to go away too, do you?"
Simon Peter answered him, "Lord, to whom shall we go? You have words of eternal life,
and we have come to trust and have come to know that you are the Holy One of God."
Jesus answered them, "Did I not choose you, the Twelve? And yet one of you is a devil."
He was speaking of Judas, son of Simon Iscariot, for this one—one of the Twelve—was about to betray him.

chapters.notes:
**"Judeans" (vv. 4, 41, 52)**: The Greek Ἰουδαῖοι is typically rendered "the Jews," but in John's Gospel this term often functions more specifically to denote the religious authorities or those from Judea proper, particularly those hostile to Jesus. "Judeans" better captures this geographical and socio-religious specificity while avoiding the anachronistic implications of "Jews" as a wholesale ethnic or religious category.

**"I AM" (vv. 20, 35, 41, 48, 51)**: The Greek ἐγώ εἰμι carries the double force of simple self-identification and—especially in John's Gospel—deliberate evocation of the divine name revealed to Moses (LXX Exodus 3:14, ἐγώ εἰμι ὁ ὤν). In verse 20, where Jesus walks on the water, the emphatic "I AM" announces divine presence. In the bread discourse, the formula becomes a revelatory refrain identifying Jesus with the divine identity. English "I am" is too weak; "I AM" preserves the solemnity and theological weight.

**"Trust" for πιστεύω (throughout)**: While "believe" is traditional, πιστεύω in John carries the stronger sense of active trust, reliance, and commitment—not merely intellectual assent. "Trust" better captures this relational dimension, especially when the verb takes εἰς ("trust in/into") indicating movement toward and union with its object.

**"The one who feeds on" for ὁ τρώγων (vv. 54, 56, 57, 58)**: John shifts from the more common φαγεῖν (to eat) to the more visceral τρώγειν, which suggests chewing, gnawing, or audibly consuming. "Feeds on" conveys this more physical, ongoing action without resorting to crude literalism.

**"Looking upon" for θεωρῶν (v. 40)**: Not merely "seeing" (ὁράω) but contemplative beholding or observing—the kind of sustained, attentive seeing that leads to recognition and faith.

**"Harsh" for σκληρός (v. 60)**: The word means hard, difficult, offensive—not simply "difficult to understand" but difficult to accept. "Harsh" captures the disciples' sense that this teaching is offensively demanding.

**"To the things behind" (v. 66)**: The phrase εἰς τὰ ὀπίσω is literally "to the back things" or "backward"—they returned to their former way of life, abandoning forward movement with Jesus.

**"Performers" avoided in "grumbling"**: The verb γογγύζω (vv. 41, 43, 61) specifically means to grumble or murmur in complaint, echoing Israel's wilderness murmuring (Exodus 16:2ff LXX). This is not theatrical performance but discontent—"grumbling" is precise here.

**"Two hundred denarii" (v. 7)**: Retained the specific amount rather than converting to vague modern equivalents. A denarius was a day's wage for a laborer; the specificity matters for understanding the scale of the miracle.

**Historical present tense**: John frequently uses the present tense for past events to create vividness (the "historical present"). I've generally preserved this where it flows naturally in English (e.g., "he says" rather than "he said") to maintain the narrative's immediacy.

verses.text: After these things, Jesus traveled about in Galilee. He did not want to move about in Judea, because the Judean authorities were seeking to kill him.
Now the Jewish feast of Tabernacles was near.
So his brothers said to him, "Leave here and go to Judea, so that your disciples there may also observe the works you are doing.
For no one does anything in secret while seeking to be known publicly. If you are doing these things, reveal yourself to the world."
For not even his brothers believed in him.
Jesus therefore said to them, "My time has not yet arrived, but your time is always ready.
The world cannot hate you, but it hates me, because I testify concerning it that its works are evil.
You go up to the feast. I am not going up to this feast, because my time has not yet been fulfilled."
Having said these things to them, he remained in Galilee.
But when his brothers had gone up to the feast, then he also went up—not openly, but as though in secret.
The Judean authorities were therefore looking for him at the feast and saying, "Where is that man?"
And there was much murmuring about him among the crowds. Some were saying, "He is good," but others were saying, "No, rather he is leading the crowd astray."
Yet no one was speaking openly about him because of their fear of the Judean authorities.
Already at the middle of the feast, Jesus went up to the temple and began teaching.
The Judean authorities were therefore amazed, saying, "How does this man know the Scriptures, having never been trained?"
Jesus therefore answered them and said, "My teaching is not mine, but belongs to the one who sent me.
If anyone desires to do his will, that person will know concerning the teaching—whether it comes from God, or whether I am speaking from myself.
The one who speaks from himself seeks his own glory, but the one who seeks the glory of the one who sent him—this person is true, and there is no unrighteousness in him.
Did not Moses give you the law? Yet none of you keeps the law. Why are you seeking to kill me?"
The crowd answered, "You have a demon! Who is seeking to kill you?"
Jesus answered and said to them, "I performed one work, and you are all astonished.
Because of this, Moses has given you circumcision—not that it comes from Moses, but from the fathers—and you circumcise a man on the Sabbath.
If a man receives circumcision on the Sabbath so that the law of Moses may not be broken, are you angry with me because I made an entire man well on the Sabbath?
Stop judging by outward appearance, but judge with right judgment."
Some of the people from Jerusalem were therefore saying, "Is this not the man they are seeking to kill?
And look—he is speaking openly, and they are saying nothing to him! Can it be that the rulers have truly recognized that this man is the Messiah?
But we know where this man is from. Yet when the Messiah comes, no one will know where he is from."

Jesus therefore cried out in the temple as he was teaching, saying, "You know me, and you know where I am from! Yet I have not come on my own initiative, but the one who sent me is true—the one whom you do not know.
I know him, because I am from him, and he sent me."
They were therefore seeking to seize him, but no one laid a hand on him, because his hour had not yet come.
Yet many from the crowd believed in him, and they were saying, "When the Messiah comes, will he perform more signs than this man has performed?"
The Pharisees heard the crowd murmuring these things about him, and the chief priests and the Pharisees sent temple guards to seize him.
Jesus therefore said, "I am with you for only a short time longer, and then I am going to the one who sent me.
You will search for me and will not find me, and where I am, you cannot come."
The Judean authorities therefore said to one another, "Where is this man about to go that we will not find him? He is not going to the Dispersion among the Greeks to teach the Greeks, is he?
What is this statement he made: 'You will search for me and will not find me, and where I am, you cannot come'?"
Now on the last day of the feast, the great day, Jesus stood and cried out, saying, "If anyone thirsts, let him come to me and drink.
The one who believes in me, as the Scripture has said, 'Rivers of living water will flow from within him.'"
Now he said this concerning the Spirit, which those who believed in him were about to receive—for the Spirit was not yet given, because Jesus had not yet been glorified.
Some from the crowd, therefore, when they heard these words, were saying, "This is truly the Prophet."
Others were saying, "This is the Messiah." But some were saying, "Surely the Messiah does not come from Galilee, does he?
Has not the Scripture said that the Messiah comes from the seed of David, and from Bethlehem, the village where David was?"
So a division occurred in the crowd because of him.
Some of them wanted to seize him, but no one laid hands on him.
The temple guards therefore came to the chief priests and Pharisees, and those men said to them, "Why did you not bring him?"
The guards answered, "Never has anyone spoken like this."
The Pharisees therefore answered them, "Have you also been led astray?
Has any one of the rulers believed in him, or any of the Pharisees?
But this crowd that does not know the law—they are accursed!"
Nicodemus, the one who had come to him earlier, being one of them, said to them,
"Our law does not judge a man unless it first hears from him and learns what he is doing, does it?"
They answered and said to him, "You are not also from Galilee, are you? Search and see that no prophet arises from Galilee."

chapters.notes:
**"Judean authorities" (vv. 1, 11, 13, 15, 35)**: The Greek οἱ Ἰουδαῖοι is notoriously difficult. In John's Gospel, it often refers not to Jewish people generally (Jesus and his disciples were themselves Jewish), but to the religious-political leadership centered in Jerusalem who opposed Jesus. Context determines meaning: in v. 13 it clearly means "authorities" (the crowd fears them); in v. 2 it simply means "Jewish" (as a descriptor of the feast). I've translated contextually, using "Judean authorities" where the term refers to the hostile leadership, and "Jewish" where it's a religious-ethnic descriptor.

**"Brothers" (vv. 3, 5, 10)**: The Greek ἀδελφοί. These are Jesus's siblings (see Mark 6:3 for their names). Some theological traditions understand these as cousins or step-siblings, but the natural reading of the Greek supports biological brothers.

**"My time" / "my hour"** (vv. 6, 8, 30): Jesus uses both καιρός (appointed time, right moment) and ὥρα (hour) to refer to the time of his death and glorification, a major theme in John's Gospel. The terms are nearly synonymous in this context but I've preserved the distinction where it appears.

**"Leading the crowd astray" (v. 12)**: The verb πλανάω means to cause to wander, deceive, lead astray—with connotations of leading someone off the true path. This is more specific than generic deception.

**"Know the Scriptures" (v. 15)**: Literally "know letters/writings" (γράμματα). This refers to formal training in the sacred texts, not mere literacy. The authorities are astonished that Jesus can interpret Scripture at a professional level without having studied under recognized teachers.

**"Outward appearance" (v. 24)**: The Greek κατ' ὄψιν means "according to face/appearance"—judging by surface-level observation rather than penetrating to truth.

**"The Prophet" (v. 40)**: With the definite article, this refers to the prophet like Moses promised in Deuteronomy 18:15-18, a specific messianic expectation.

**"The Dispersion among the Greeks" (v. 35)**: ἡ διασπορὰ τῶν Ἑλλήνων—the Jewish Diaspora living in Greek-speaking lands outside Palestine. Their question drips with irony: would Jesus leave the holy land to teach among scattered Jews and Gentiles?

**"Rivers of living water will flow from within him" (v. 38)**: The quotation doesn't match any single Old Testament text precisely but alludes to several passages about water flowing from Jerusalem/the temple (Ezekiel 47:1-12, Zechariah 14:8, Isaiah 58:11). The Greek κοιλία can mean belly, womb, or innermost being—I've used "within him" to capture the sense of an interior source.

**"The Spirit was not yet given" (v. 39)**: The Greek literally says "the Spirit was not yet" (οὔπω γὰρ ἦν πνεῦμα), which sounds odd. I've added "given" as this is clearly the sense—the Spirit would be given after Jesus's glorification (his death, resurrection, and ascension). Some manuscripts add "given" or "upon them."

**"Accursed" (v. 49)**: ἐπάρατοι—literally "cursed" or "under a curse." This is harsh religious language, expressing contempt for those not trained in the law.

verses.text: Again, therefore, Jesus spoke to them, saying: "I am the light of the world. The one who follows me will never walk in darkness, but will have the light of life."
So the Pharisees said to him, "You are testifying about yourself; your testimony is not valid."

Jesus answered and said to them, "Even if I testify about myself, my testimony is valid, because I know where I came from and where I am going. But you do not know where I come from or where I am going.
You judge according to the flesh; I judge no one.
Yet even if I do judge, my judgment is true, because I am not alone—rather, I and the Father who sent me.
And it is written in your own law that the testimony of two persons is valid.
I am the one testifying about myself, and the Father who sent me testifies about me."
So they were saying to him, "Where is your father?" Jesus answered, "You know neither me nor my Father. If you knew me, you would know my Father as well."
He spoke these words in the treasury while teaching in the temple. And no one arrested him, because his hour had not yet come.
So he said to them again, "I am going away, and you will search for me, and you will die in your sin. Where I am going, you cannot come."
So the Judeans were saying, "Surely he's not going to kill himself, is he? Because he says, 'Where I am going, you cannot come.'"
And he was saying to them, "You are from below; I am from above. You are from this world; I am not from this world.
I said to you that you will die in your sins. For if you do not believe that I am, you will die in your sins."
So they were saying to him, "Who are you?" Jesus said to them, "Why am I even speaking to you at all?
I have many things to say about you and to judge. But the one who sent me is true, and what I have heard from him, these things I speak into the world."
They did not understand that he was speaking to them about the Father.
So Jesus said, "When you lift up the Son of Man, then you will know that I am, and that I do nothing on my own authority, but I speak these things just as the Father taught me.
And the one who sent me is with me. He has not left me alone, because I always do what is pleasing to him."
As he was speaking these things, many believed in him.
So Jesus was saying to the Judeans who had believed in him, "If you remain in my word, you are truly my disciples,
and you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free."
They answered him, "We are Abraham's offspring and have never been enslaved to anyone. How can you say, 'You will become free'?"
Jesus answered them, "Truly, truly, I tell you: everyone who commits sin is a slave of sin.
Now the slave does not remain in the household forever; the son remains forever.
So if the Son sets you free, you will be truly free.
I know that you are Abraham's offspring. Yet you are seeking to kill me, because my word finds no place in you.
I speak what I have seen with the Father; so also you do what you have heard from your father."
They answered and said to him, "Our father is Abraham." Jesus says to them, "If you are Abraham's children, you would be doing the works of Abraham.
But now you are seeking to kill me—a man who has spoken to you the truth that I heard from God. Abraham did not do this.
You are doing the works of your father." They said to him, "We were not born of sexual immorality. We have one Father—God."
Jesus said to them, "If God were your Father, you would love me, for I came forth from God and have arrived here. For I have not come on my own authority, but that one sent me.
Why do you not understand my speech? Because you cannot hear my word.

You are of your father the devil, and you want to carry out the desires of your father. He was a murderer from the beginning, and does not stand in the truth, because there is no truth in him. When he speaks the lie, he speaks from his own nature, because he is a liar and the father of it.
But because I speak the truth, you do not believe me.
Which of you convicts me of sin? If I speak truth, why do you not believe me?
The one who is from God hears the words of God. For this reason you do not hear: because you are not from God."
The Judeans answered and said to him, "Are we not right in saying that you are a Samaritan and have a demon?"
Jesus answered, "I do not have a demon, but I honor my Father, and you dishonor me.
Yet I do not seek my own glory; there is one who seeks it and judges.
Truly, truly, I tell you: if anyone keeps my word, he will never see death forever."
The Judeans said to him, "Now we know that you have a demon. Abraham died, and so did the prophets, yet you say, 'If anyone keeps my word, he will never taste death forever.'
You are not greater than our father Abraham, are you? He died, and the prophets died. Who do you make yourself out to be?"
Jesus answered, "If I glorify myself, my glory is nothing. It is my Father who glorifies me—the one about whom you say, 'He is our God.'
Yet you have not known him, but I know him. And if I were to say that I do not know him, I would be a liar like you. But I do know him, and I keep his word.
Abraham your father rejoiced that he might see my day, and he saw it and was glad."
So the Judeans said to him, "You are not yet fifty years old, and you have seen Abraham?"
Jesus said to them, "Truly, truly, I tell you: before Abraham came into being, I am."
So they picked up stones to throw at them. But Jesus hid himself and went out from the temple.

chapters.notes:
**"Judeans" (οἱ Ἰουδαῖοι)**: Throughout this passage, I've translated this as "Judeans" rather than the traditional "Jews." In John's Gospel, this term often functions as a technical designation for the Jerusalem religious authorities and their allies, not as a general ethnic or religious label. The conflict is regional and institutional (Galilean Jesus vs. Jerusalem establishment), not ethnic. The first-century audience would have understood this specificity.

**"I am" (ἐγώ εἰμι, verses 24, 28, 58)**: This phrase echoes Exodus 3:14 (LXX: ἐγώ εἰμι ὁ ὤν, "I am the one who is"), where God reveals his name to Moses. In verse 58, it is grammatically absolute and theologically explosive—Jesus claims eternal, pre-existent identity using the divine name. The verse structure deliberately contrasts created being (γενέσθαι, "to come into being") with eternal existence (εἰμί, "I am"). Their violent response (v. 59) shows they understood this as a divine claim.

**"Your own law" (v. 17)**: Jesus says τῷ νόμῳ... τῷ ὑμετέρῳ ("your law"), creating distance between himself and the Torah. This is significant in John's christology—Jesus stands outside and above the Mosaic dispensation as its fulfillment and judge.

**"Where I am going, you cannot come" (v. 21-22)**: The irony is tragic. Jesus speaks of ascending to the Father; they wonder if he means suicide. Suicide would bring ritual uncleanness and separation from God—the opposite of Jesus's destination. They comprehend his words only at the fleshly level (v. 15).

**"My word finds no place in you" (v. 37)**: The verb χωρεῖ means "to have space for, to make room for, to advance into." It's spatial imagery—Jesus's word cannot gain ground in them, cannot find lodging, is blocked from entry.

**"The lie" (v. 44)**: The Greek τὸ ψεῦδος has the definite article—"the lie," not just "lies." In context, this likely refers to the fundamental deception in Eden (Genesis 3), where the serpent contradicted God's word. The devil is the originator and father of that primal falsehood.

**"He is a liar and the father of it" (v. 44)**: The phrase ὁ πατὴρ αὐτοῦ is ambiguous—it could mean "the father of the lie" or "the father of the liar" (referring to anyone who lies). I've translated "the father of it" to preserve the ambiguity, though the former reading (father of the lie itself) fits the immediate context better.

**"Why am I even speaking to you at all?" (v. 25)**: This verse is notoriously difficult. The Greek Τὴν ἀρχὴν ὅ τι καὶ λαλῶ ὑμῖν could mean: (1) "From the beginning, what I have been telling you," (2) "Why am I speaking to you at all?" or (3) "I am the beginning, which is what I am telling you." I've chosen option 2, understanding it as Jesus's exasperated response to their obtuseness—a rhetorical question expressing frustration at their inability to understand even after extensive explanation.

**"Sexual immorality" (πορνεία, v. 41)**: Their protest "We were not born of sexual immorality" may be: (1) an assertion of legitimate Israelite descent (not mixed ancestry like Samaritans), (2) a veiled insult about Jesus's birth circumstances (the virgin birth could be misunderstood as illegitimacy), or (3) a theological claim that they are not spiritually adulterous like Israel's past idolatry. All three layers may be present to the original audience.

**"He saw it and was glad" (v. 56)**: Jesus claims Abraham foresaw the Messiah's coming. This may allude to Genesis 17:17 (Abraham's laughter at the promise) or to rabbinic traditions about Abraham's eschatological vision. The original audience, steeped in interpretive traditions, would have recognized such prophetic foresight as plausible.

verses.text: And as he was passing by, he saw a man who had been blind from birth.
His disciples asked him, "Rabbi, who sinned—this man or his parents—that he should be born blind?"
Jesus answered, "Neither this man sinned nor his parents. Rather, this happened so that the works of God might be made visible in him.
We must work the works of the one who sent me while it is day. Night is coming, when no one can work.
While I am in the world, I am the light of the world."
Having said these things, he spat on the ground and made mud from the saliva, and he spread the mud on his eyes.
Then he said to him, "Go, wash in the pool of Siloam" (which is translated "Sent One"). So he went off and washed, and he came back seeing.
Then the neighbors and those who had previously observed him begging were saying, "Isn't this the one who used to sit and beg?"
Some were saying, "This is the man." Others were saying, "No, but he looks like him." The man himself kept saying, "I am the one."
So they said to him, "How then were your eyes opened?"
He answered, "The man called Jesus made mud and spread it on my eyes and said to me, 'Go to Siloam and wash.' So I went, and when I had washed, I received my sight."
They said to him, "Where is he?" He said, "I don't know."
They brought him to the Pharisees—the man who had once been blind.
Now it was a Sabbath day on which Jesus made the mud and opened his eyes.
So the Pharisees also began questioning him about how he had received his sight. He said to them, "He put mud on my eyes, and I washed, and now I see."

Therefore some of the Pharisees were saying, "This man is not from God, because he does not keep the Sabbath." But others were saying, "How can a sinful man perform such signs?" And there was a division among them.
So they said to the blind man again, "What do you say about him, since he opened your eyes?" He said, "He is a prophet."
Now the Judean authorities did not believe the facts about him—that he had been blind and had received his sight—until they summoned the parents of the man who had received his sight.
They questioned them, saying, "Is this your son, whom you say was born blind? How then does he now see?"
His parents answered, "We know that this is our son and that he was born blind.
But how he now sees, we do not know, nor do we know who opened his eyes. Ask him—he is of age. He will speak for himself."

His parents said these things because they were afraid of the Judean authorities, for the Judean authorities had already agreed that if anyone should acknowledge him as the Messiah, that person would be expelled from the synagogue.
This is why his parents said, "He is of age; question him."
So they summoned the man a second time—the one who had been blind—and said to him, "Give glory to God. We know that this man is a sinner."
He answered, "Whether he is a sinner, I do not know. One thing I do know: that though I was blind, now I see."
They said to him, "What did he do to you? How did he open your eyes?"
He answered them, "I have already told you, and you did not listen. Why do you want to hear it again? You don't want to become his disciples too, do you?"
Then they reviled him and said, "You are a disciple of that man, but we are disciples of Moses.
We know that God has spoken to Moses, but as for this man, we do not know where he is from."
The man answered and said to them, "Well, here is something remarkable: that you do not know where he is from, and yet he opened my eyes.
We know that God does not listen to sinners, but if anyone is devout and does his will, God listens to that person.
Never in all history has it been heard that anyone opened the eyes of a person born blind.
If this man were not from God, he could do nothing."
They answered and said to him, "You were born entirely in sins, and you are teaching us?" And they threw him out.
Jesus heard that they had thrown him out, and when he found him, he said, "Do you believe in the Son of Man?"
He answered, "And who is he, sir, that I may believe in him?"
Jesus said to him, "You have both seen him, and he is the one speaking with you."
He said, "I believe, Lord," and he worshipped him.
And Jesus said, "For judgment I came into this world, so that those who do not see may see, and those who see may become blind."
Some of the Pharisees who were with him heard these things and said to him, "Surely we are not blind too, are we?"
Jesus said to them, "If you were blind, you would have no sin. But now you say, 'We see.' Your sin remains."

chapters.notes:
**"Judean authorities" (vv. 18, 22)**: The Greek οἱ Ἰουδαῖοι presents a translation challenge throughout John's Gospel. While often rendered "the Jews," this creates confusion since Jesus and his disciples were themselves Jewish. In John's narrative, the term frequently refers specifically to the Jerusalem-based religious leadership hostile to Jesus. "Judean authorities" captures this institutional sense while avoiding the anachronism of ethnic/religious categories that would make all parties "Jewish."

**"Expelled from the synagogue" (v. 22)**: The term ἀποσυνάγωγος refers to formal excommunication from the synagogue community. This was not merely social ostracism but cut one off from religious participation and communal life, a severe penalty in first-century Jewish society.

**"Give glory to God" (v. 24)**: This was a formal oath formula used to compel truthful testimony (see Joshua 7:19). The Pharisees are not praising God but rather demanding that the man swear an oath and confirm their version of events—that Jesus is a sinner.

**"Never in all history" (v. 32)**: The phrase ἐκ τοῦ αἰῶνος literally means "from the age" but idiomatically refers to all recorded time or history. The man is making a dramatic rhetorical point about the unprecedented nature of the miracle.

**"Son of Man" (v. 35)**: This preserves Jesus's characteristic self-designation, which carries both messianic overtones (Daniel 7:13-14) and an emphasis on his humanity and representative role.

**"You have both seen him" (v. 37)**: There is wordplay here impossible to fully preserve in English. The man who was physically blind and is now able to see is told that he has "seen" (ἑώρακας) the Son of Man—both literally with his new sight and spiritually through recognition of Jesus's identity.

**"For judgment" (v. 39)**: The Greek εἰς κρίμα indicates purpose. Jesus came to bring about a crisis of judgment that would reveal people's true spiritual condition—those who acknowledge their blindness can receive sight, while those who claim to see remain in darkness.

verses.text: Truly, truly I tell you: the one who does not enter through the door into the sheepfold but climbs in some other way—that one is a thief and a bandit.
But the one who enters through the door is the shepherd of the sheep.
The doorkeeper opens for him, and the sheep hear his voice. He calls his own sheep by name and leads them out.
When he has brought out all his own, he goes ahead of them, and the sheep follow him because they know his voice.
But they will never follow a stranger; instead they will flee from him, because they do not know the voice of strangers.
Jesus spoke this figure of speech to them, but they did not understand what he was saying to them.
So Jesus said to them again: Truly, truly I tell you, I am the door of the sheep.
All who came before me are thieves and bandits, but the sheep did not listen to them.
I am the door. If anyone enters through me, he will be saved—he will come in and go out and find pasture.
The thief comes only to steal and slaughter and destroy. I have come so that they may have life, and have it abundantly.
I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep.
The hired hand, who is not the shepherd and does not own the sheep, sees the wolf coming and abandons the sheep and flees—and the wolf snatches them and scatters them—
because he is a hired hand and does not care about the sheep.
I am the good shepherd. I know my own and my own know me,
just as the Father knows me and I know the Father. And I lay down my life for the sheep.
I have other sheep that are not of this fold. I must bring them also, and they will hear my voice. Then there will be one flock, one shepherd.
This is why the Father loves me: because I lay down my life so that I may take it up again.
No one takes it from me, but I lay it down of my own accord. I have authority to lay it down, and I have authority to take it up again. This command I received from my Father.
A division occurred again among the Judeans because of these words.
Many of them were saying, "He has a demon and is out of his mind. Why are you listening to him?"
Others were saying, "These are not the words of someone demon-possessed. A demon cannot open the eyes of the blind, can it?"
At that time the Festival of Dedication took place in Jerusalem. It was winter,
and Jesus was walking in the temple, in Solomon's Colonnade.
The Judeans gathered around him and said to him, "How long will you keep us in suspense? If you are the Messiah, tell us plainly."
Jesus answered them, "I have told you, and you do not believe. The works that I do in my Father's name—these testify about me.
But you do not believe because you are not of my sheep.
My sheep hear my voice. I know them, and they follow me.
I give them eternal life, and they will never perish, and no one will snatch them out of my hand.
My Father, who has given them to me, is greater than all, and no one is able to snatch them out of the Father's hand.
I and the Father are one."
The Judeans picked up stones again to stone him.
Jesus answered them, "I have shown you many good works from the Father. For which of these works are you stoning me?"
The Judeans answered him, "We are not stoning you for a good work but for blasphemy—because you, being a man, make yourself God."
Jesus answered them, "Is it not written in your law, 'I said, you are gods'?
If he called them 'gods'—those to whom the word of God came, and the scripture cannot be broken—
do you say of the one whom the Father consecrated and sent into the world, 'You are blaspheming,' because I said, 'I am the Son of God'?
If I am not doing the works of my Father, do not believe me.
But if I am doing them, even if you do not believe me, believe the works, so that you may come to know and continue to know that the Father is in me and I am in the Father."
Then they tried again to seize him, but he escaped from their hands.
He went away again across the Jordan to the place where John had been baptizing at first, and he remained there.
Many came to him and were saying, "John performed no sign, but everything John said about this man was true."
And many believed in him there.

chapters.notes:
**"Truly, truly"**: The doubled ἀμὴν ἀμήν is a solemn formula unique to John's Gospel, representing the Hebrew/Aramaic אָמֵן. This emphatic doubling marks Jesus's words as carrying divine authority.

**"Bandit" (λῃστής)**: This term denotes not merely a petty thief but a violent robber or insurgent—someone who takes by force. In first-century Judean context, it often referred to revolutionary brigands. The pairing with κλέπτης (thief, stealth-thief) covers both covert and violent forms of predation.

**"Figure of speech" (παροιμία)**: Not quite "parable" (παραβολή), which John never uses. This term suggests a veiled saying, proverb, or figurative discourse—something requiring interpretation.

**"Good shepherd" (ποιμὴν ὁ καλός)**: While καλός can mean "beautiful," in this context it carries the sense of "noble, excellent, exemplary"—the shepherd who embodies the ideal. The background is Ezekiel 34, where God condemns Israel's failed shepherds and promises to shepherd his people himself.

**"Lay down" (τίθημι)**: Rather than the more common "give up," this verb emphasizes the voluntary, deliberate nature of the action—Jesus places his life down by choice.

**"Abundantly" (περισσὸν ἔχωσιν)**: The phrase literally means "have in excess" or "have overflowing"—life not just preserved but flourishing beyond mere survival.

**"Judeans" (Ἰουδαῖοι)**: This term in John's Gospel is complex. While often translated "Jews," it frequently refers specifically to the Judean authorities or inhabitants of Judea who oppose Jesus, not to Jewish people generally. The context usually indicates religious-political leadership. I've used "Judeans" to preserve this ambiguity and avoid anachronistic readings.

**"Keep us in suspense" (τὴν ψυχὴν ἡμῶν αἴρεις)**: Literally "lift up our soul/life." This idiom means to keep someone in anxious uncertainty or doubt—holding them suspended.

**"Messiah" (χριστός)**: While often transliterated as "Christ," in this context the interrogators are asking about the expected Jewish deliverer-king, so "Messiah" better captures the original sense for modern readers.

**"Are one" (ἕν ἐσμεν)**: The neuter ἕν (not masculine εἷς) indicates unity of essence or purpose, not numerical identity. This is the claim that provokes the charge of blasphemy.

**"Your law"**: Jesus's distancing language ("your law" rather than "our law") is characteristic of John's presentation of Jesus's relationship to Jewish authority structures.
