**"Come to know and continue to know" (γνῶτε καὶ γινώσκητε)**: The aorist followed by the present subjunctive suggests both an initial realization and an ongoing, deepening knowledge.

**"Escaped from their hands" (ἐξῆλθεν ἐκ τῆς χειρὸς αὐτῶν)**: The language suggests a mysterious departure—he went out from their grasp, implying either supernatural evasion or the crowd's inability to hold him.

verses.text: Now there was a man who was ill—Lazarus from Bethany, from the village of Mary and her sister Martha.
(This Mary was the one who anointed the Lord with perfumed oil and wiped his feet with her hair; it was her brother Lazarus who was ill.)
So the sisters sent word to him, saying, "Lord, look—the one you love is ill."
But when Jesus heard this, he said, "This illness is not destined for death, but rather for the glory of God, so that the Son of God may be glorified through it."
Now Jesus loved Martha and her sister and Lazarus.
So when he heard that Lazarus was ill, he actually remained in the place where he was for two more days.
Then after this he says to the disciples, "Let us go back to Judea."
The disciples say to him, "Rabbi, the Judeans were just now trying to stone you, and you're going back there again?"
Jesus answered, "Are there not twelve hours in the day? If anyone walks during the day, he does not stumble, because he sees the light of this world.
But if anyone walks during the night, he stumbles, because the light is not in him."
He said these things, and after this he tells them, "Our friend Lazarus has fallen asleep, but I am going so that I may awaken him."
So the disciples said to him, "Lord, if he has fallen asleep, he will recover."
Jesus had been speaking about his death, but they supposed that he was speaking about the rest that comes from sleep.
So then Jesus told them plainly, "Lazarus has died,
and I am glad for your sake that I was not there, so that you may believe. But let us go to him."
Then Thomas, the one called the Twin, said to his fellow disciples, "Let us also go, so that we may die with him."
When Jesus arrived, he found that Lazarus had already been in the tomb for four days.
Now Bethany was near Jerusalem, about fifteen stadia away.
Many of the Judeans had come to Martha and Mary to console them concerning their brother.
So when Martha heard that Jesus was coming, she went out to meet him, while Mary remained sitting in the house.
Martha said to Jesus, "Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died.
But even now I know that whatever you ask from God, God will give you."
Jesus says to her, "Your brother will rise again."
Martha says to him, "I know that he will rise again in the resurrection on the last day."
Jesus said to her, "I am the resurrection and the life. The one who believes in me, even if he dies, will live,
and everyone who lives and believes in me will never die—not ever. Do you believe this?"
She says to him, "Yes, Lord. I have come to believe that you are the Messiah, the Son of God, the one coming into the world."
And having said this, she went away and called her sister Mary privately, saying, "The Teacher is here and is calling for you."
When she heard this, she got up quickly and went to him.
Now Jesus had not yet entered the village, but was still in the place where Martha had met him.
So the Judeans who were with her in the house, consoling her, when they saw Mary get up quickly and go out, followed her, supposing that she was going to the tomb to weep there.
Then when Mary came to where Jesus was and saw him, she fell at his feet, saying to him, "Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died."
When Jesus saw her weeping, and the Judeans who came with her also weeping, he was deeply moved in spirit and troubled within himself.
He said, "Where have you laid him?" They say to him, "Lord, come and see."
Jesus wept.
So the Judeans were saying, "See how much he loved him!"
But some of them said, "Could not this man, who opened the eyes of the blind man, have done something so that this man would not die?"
Then Jesus, again deeply moved within himself, comes to the tomb. It was a cave, and a stone was lying against it.
Jesus says, "Remove the stone." Martha, the sister of the one who had died, says to him, "Lord, by now there will be a stench, for it has been four days."
Jesus says to her, "Did I not tell you that if you believe, you will see the glory of God?"
So they removed the stone. Then Jesus lifted his eyes upward and said, "Father, I thank you that you heard me.
I myself knew that you always hear me, but I spoke because of the crowd standing around, so that they may believe that you sent me."
And having said these things, he cried out with a loud voice, "Lazarus, come out!"
The dead man came out, his feet and hands bound with strips of linen, and his face wrapped with a burial cloth. Jesus says to them, "Unbind him and let him go."
Therefore many of the Judeans who had come to Mary and had seen what he did believed in him.
But some of them went to the Pharisees and told them what Jesus had done.
So the chief priests and the Pharisees convened the council and were saying, "What are we doing? For this man is performing many signs.
If we let him go on like this, everyone will believe in him, and the Romans will come and take away both our place and our nation."
But one of them, Caiaphas, who was high priest that year, said to them, "You know nothing at all.
You do not even consider that it is better for you that one man should die for the people than that the whole nation should perish."
Now he did not say this on his own initiative, but being high priest that year, he prophesied that Jesus was about to die for the nation—
and not only for the nation, but also in order to gather into one the scattered children of God.
So from that day on they resolved to kill him.
Therefore Jesus no longer walked about openly among the Judeans, but went away from there to the region near the wilderness, to a town called Ephraim, and there he remained with the disciples.
Now the Passover of the Judeans was near, and many went up to Jerusalem from the countryside before the Passover to purify themselves.
So they were looking for Jesus and saying to one another as they stood in the temple, "What do you think? Surely he will not come to the festival, will he?"
Now the chief priests and the Pharisees had given orders that if anyone knew where he was, they should report it, so that they might arrest him.

chapters.notes:
**"The Judeans" (throughout)**: The Greek οἱ Ἰουδαῖοι in John's Gospel is complex. It sometimes means the religious authorities (especially in Jerusalem), sometimes the inhabitants of Judea as distinct from Galilee or Samaria, and sometimes Jewish people generally. In this chapter, the context suggests the term primarily refers to people from Judea—hence "the Judeans" rather than the anachronistic "the Jews." This maintains the geographical and political specificity John intends while avoiding the later theological freight that "the Jews" has acquired.

**"Deeply moved" (v. 33, 38)**: The verb ἐμβριμάομαι (ἐνεβριμήσατο, ἐμβριμώμενος) is notoriously difficult. It can mean "snort with anger" (like a horse), "scold," or "express deep emotion." Traditional translations often soften it to "troubled" or "deeply moved," but the term carries a note of indignation or intense emotional disturbance. "Deeply moved" captures the intensity while acknowledging the interpretive difficulty—Jesus is not merely sad but profoundly agitated, whether at death itself, at unbelief, or at the mourning before him.

**"The one you love" vs. "loved"**: In verse 3, the sisters use φιλέω (love/affection), which Jesus echoes in verse 11 calling Lazarus "our friend" (φίλος). In verse 5, the narrator uses ἀγαπάω (love) for Jesus's love of all three siblings. In verse 36, the Judeans use ἐφίλει (past tense of φιλέω). John often uses these terms interchangeably (see John 21), so I have not forced a sharp distinction, but retained "love" and "loved" to reflect the semantic field of affection and friendship.

**"Will recover" (v. 12)**: The Greek σωθήσεται literally means "will be saved," but in the context of physical sleep and illness, the disciples clearly mean "will get better/recover." The verb σῴζω has a range from physical deliverance to spiritual salvation; context determines the sense.

**"The Twin" (v. 16)**: Δίδυμος is Greek for "twin," translating the Aramaic name Thomas (תאומא, *te'oma*). I have rendered it "the Twin" to show that it functions as a descriptive title.

**"Stadia" (v. 18)**: A stadion (plural stadia) was roughly 185 meters or 607 feet. Fifteen stadia equals about 1.7 miles or 2.8 kilometers. I retained "stadia" as it preserves the ancient measurement system without imposing anachronistic conversions.

**"Never die—not ever" (v. 26)**: The Greek οὐ μὴ ἀποθάνῃ εἰς τὸν αἰῶνα uses the strongest form of negation (οὐ μή) combined with the temporal phrase "into the age/forever." The double negative construction in Greek (which creates an emphatic positive in meaning) is captured by the emphatic English rendering "never... not ever."

**"I have come to believe" (v. 27)**: The perfect tense πεπίστευκα indicates completed action with ongoing results—Martha's belief is not just a past event but a present reality. "I have come to believe" captures this better than "I believe."

**"Troubled within himself" (v. 33)**: The phrase ἐτάραξεν ἑαυτόν is reflexive—literally "he troubled himself" or "he agitated himself." This is an unusual construction suggesting Jesus deliberately allowed himself to experience profound emotional disturbance.

**"Burial cloth" (v. 44)**: The σουδάριον was a cloth used to cover the face of the deceased. "Burial cloth" is more specific than "cloth" and clearer than the transliterated "sudarium."

**"Resolved" (v. 53)**: The verb ἐβουλεύσαντο means to deliberate and reach a decision—"they resolved" captures both the deliberative process and the decision reached.

**"Our place" (v. 48)**: The τόπος ("place") likely refers to the temple, the geographic center of Jewish religious and political life under Roman occupation.

verses.text: Six days before the Passover, Jesus came to Bethany, where Lazarus was—the one Jesus had raised from the dead.
So they prepared a dinner for him there. Martha was serving, and Lazarus was one of those reclining at the table with him.
Then Mary took a Roman pound of perfume—pure nard oil, very costly—and anointed the feet of Jesus and wiped his feet with her hair. And the house was filled with the fragrance of the perfume.
But Judas Iscariot, one of his disciples—the one who was about to betray him—said,
"Why was this perfume not sold for three hundred denarii and the money given to the poor?"
He said this not because he cared about the poor, but because he was a thief; he kept the money box and used to pilfer what was put into it.
Jesus said, "Leave her alone, so that she may keep it for the day of my burial preparation.
For the poor you always have with you, but you do not always have me."
Now a large crowd from among the Judeans learned that he was there, and they came not only because of Jesus but also to see Lazarus, whom he had raised from the dead.
So the chief priests plotted to kill Lazarus as well,
because on account of him many of the Judeans were going over and believing in Jesus.
The next day, the large crowd that had come for the festival heard that Jesus was coming to Jerusalem.
So they took branches of palm trees and went out to meet him, and they were shouting: "Hosanna! Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the Lord—even the King of Israel!"
And Jesus, finding a young donkey, sat on it, just as it is written:
"Do not fear, daughter of Zion; look, your king is coming, seated on a donkey's colt."
His disciples did not understand these things at first, but when Jesus was glorified, then they remembered that these things had been written about him and that they had done these things to him.
So the crowd that had been with him when he called Lazarus out of the tomb and raised him from the dead continued to bear witness.
This is also why the crowd went to meet him—because they heard that he had performed this sign.
The Pharisees therefore said to one another, "You see that you are accomplishing nothing. Look—the world has gone after him!"
Now there were some Greeks among those who were going up to worship at the festival.
These men approached Philip, who was from Bethsaida of Galilee, and made a request of him, saying, "Sir, we wish to see Jesus."
Philip went and told Andrew; Andrew and Philip went and told Jesus.
Jesus answered them, saying, "The hour has come for the Son of Man to be glorified.
Truly, truly I tell you: unless the grain of wheat falls into the earth and dies, it remains alone; but if it dies, it bears much fruit.
The one who loves his life destroys it, and the one who hates his life in this world will preserve it for eternal life.
If anyone serves me, let him follow me, and where I am, there my servant will also be. If anyone serves me, the Father will honor him.
"Now my soul is troubled. And what shall I say? 'Father, save me from this hour'? But it is for this very reason that I came to this hour.
Father, glorify your name." Then a voice came from heaven: "I have glorified it, and I will glorify it again."
The crowd standing there who heard it said that thunder had occurred. Others said, "An angel has spoken to him."
Jesus answered and said, "This voice has not come for my sake but for yours.
Now is the judgment of this world; now the ruler of this world will be cast out.
And I, when I am lifted up from the earth, will draw all people to myself."
He said this to indicate what kind of death he was about to die.
The crowd answered him, "We have heard from the Law that the Messiah remains forever. So how can you say that the Son of Man must be lifted up? Who is this Son of Man?"

Jesus therefore said to them, "The light is among you for a little while longer. Walk while you have the light, so that darkness may not overtake you. The one who walks in the darkness does not know where he is going.
While you have the light, believe in the light, so that you may become sons of light." After Jesus had said these things, he departed and hid himself from them.
Although he had performed so many signs in their presence, they did not believe in him,
so that the word spoken by Isaiah the prophet might be fulfilled: "Lord, who has believed our message? And to whom has the arm of the Lord been revealed?"
For this reason they were unable to believe, because Isaiah again said:
"He has blinded their eyes and hardened their heart, so that they might not see with their eyes and understand with their heart and turn back—and I would heal them."
Isaiah said these things because he saw his glory and spoke about him.
Nevertheless, even among the rulers many believed in him, but because of the Pharisees they would not openly acknowledge it, so that they would not be expelled from the synagogue.
For they loved the glory that comes from people more than the glory that comes from God.
Jesus cried out and said, "The one who believes in me believes not in me but in the one who sent me,
and the one who sees me sees the one who sent me.
I have come as light into the world, so that everyone who believes in me may not remain in darkness.
And if anyone hears my words and does not keep them, I do not judge him; for I did not come to judge the world but to save the world.
The one who rejects me and does not receive my words has his judge: the word that I have spoken—that will judge him on the last day.
For I have not spoken from myself, but the Father who sent me has himself given me commandment about what I should say and what I should speak.
And I know that his commandment is eternal life. Therefore what I speak, just as the Father has told me, so I speak."

chapters.notes:
**"Pure nard oil" (v. 3)**: The Greek πιστικῆς (pistikēs) modifying νάρδου (nard) is notoriously difficult. Options include "genuine/authentic," "liquid/distilled," or a place name. The most likely sense is "pure" or "genuine," emphasizing the quality of this expensive aromatic oil extracted from the nardostachys plant.

**"Used to pilfer" (v. 6)**: The Greek ἐβάσταζεν (literally "to carry" or "bear") in the context of ὁ κλέπτης ("thief") and keeping the money box clearly means embezzlement or theft. The imperfect tense indicates habitual action.

**"Keep it" (v. 7)**: The Greek τηρήσῃ can mean either "keep/preserve" or "observe/keep (a command)." Given the context (the anointing has already occurred), this is best understood as Jesus saying Mary should be allowed to keep/preserve what remains of the anointing for his burial preparation—or that the act itself should be understood as preserving/honoring him for burial.

**"Judeans" (v. 9, 11)**: The Greek Ἰουδαίων typically translated "Jews" more precisely means "Judeans" in this context—people from the region of Judea, as distinct from Galileans or Samaritans. The ethnic-religious sense of "Jewish" as we use it today is anachronistic for the first century.

**"Hosanna" (v. 13)**: Retained as a loanword. Originally Hebrew הוֹשִׁיעָה נָּא (hoshia na, "save now/please"), it had become a liturgical acclamation by the first century, much like "Hallelujah."

**"Greeks" (v. 20)**: Ἕλληνες could mean ethnic Greeks or Greek-speaking Gentiles more broadly—likely God-fearers (Gentile adherents to Judaism) given that they came to worship at the festival.

**"Loves his life/hates his life" (v. 25)**: The Greek φιλέω ("loves") and μισέω ("hates") represent Semitic idiom where "hate" means "love less" or "be willing to give up." This is comparative preference language, not emotional loathing.

**"Lifted up" (v. 32, 34)**: The Greek ὑψωθῶ (hypsōthō) is a characteristic Johannine double entendre: it means both "exalted/glorified" and literally "lifted up" (on the cross). The crowd's confusion in v. 34 shows they catch only the exaltation sense.

**"Arm of the Lord" (v. 38)**: Citation from Isaiah 53:1 (LXX). In Hebrew idiom, God's "arm" represents his power and saving action.

**"He has blinded" (v. 40)**: Citation from Isaiah 6:10. The divine passive construction raises theological questions about divine causation and human responsibility that John leaves in tension. The Greek preserves the active voice ("he has blinded"), referring to God as the subject, maintaining the force of the Isaiah text.

**"Sons of light" (v. 36)**: A Semitic idiom meaning "people characterized by light" or "belonging to the light." Compare the Qumran community's self-designation as "sons of light" versus "sons of darkness."

verses.text: Now before the festival of Passover, Jesus, knowing that his hour had come to pass from this world to the Father, having loved his own who were in the world, loved them to the end.
And during supper, when the devil had already put it into the heart of Judas, son of Simon Iscariot, to betray him,
Jesus—knowing that the Father had given all things into his hands, and that he had come forth from God and was going back to God—
rises from the supper and lays aside his outer garments. He took a linen towel and wrapped it around himself.
Then he pours water into the basin and began to wash the feet of the disciples and to wipe them with the towel that was wrapped around him.
So he comes to Simon Peter. He says to him, "Lord, are you going to wash my feet?"
Jesus answered and said to him, "What I am doing you do not understand now, but you will understand after these things."
Peter says to him, "You will never wash my feet—not for all eternity!" Jesus answered him, "If I do not wash you, you have no share with me."
Simon Peter says to him, "Lord, then not only my feet, but also my hands and my head!"
Jesus says to him, "The one who has bathed has no need to wash, except for the feet, but is entirely clean. And you are clean—but not all of you."
For he knew the one who was betraying him; that is why he said, "Not all of you are clean."
So when he had washed their feet and taken up his garments and reclined again, he said to them, "Do you understand what I have done for you?
You call me 'the Teacher' and 'the Lord,' and you speak rightly, for I am.
If I then, the Lord and the Teacher, have washed your feet, you also ought to wash one another's feet.
For I have given you an example, so that just as I have done for you, you also should do.
Truly, truly, I tell you: a slave is not greater than his master, nor is one who is sent out greater than the one who sent him.
If you know these things, you are blessed if you do them."
"I am not speaking about all of you—I know whom I have chosen. But the Scripture must be fulfilled: 'The one who eats my bread has lifted his heel against me.'
I am telling you now, before it happens, so that when it does happen you may believe that I AM.
Truly, truly, I tell you: whoever receives anyone I send receives me, and whoever receives me receives the one who sent me."
After saying these things, Jesus was troubled in his spirit and testified, saying, "Truly, truly, I tell you that one of you will betray me."
The disciples began looking at one another, bewildered about whom he was speaking.
One of his disciples—the one whom Jesus loved—was reclining at table close beside Jesus.
So Simon Peter motions to him to find out who it might be about whom he is speaking.
That disciple, leaning back thus against the chest of Jesus, says to him, "Lord, who is it?"
Jesus answers, "It is the one for whom I will dip the morsel and give it to him." So after dipping the morsel, he gives it to Judas, son of Simon Iscariot.
And after the morsel, then Satan entered into him. So Jesus says to him, "What you are doing, do quickly."
Now no one at the table understood why he said this to him.
For some were thinking, since Judas had the money box, that Jesus was telling him, "Buy what we need for the festival," or that he should give something to the poor.
So after receiving the morsel, that man went out immediately. And it was night.
When he had gone out, Jesus says, "Now the Son of Man is glorified, and God is glorified in him.
If God is glorified in him, God will also glorify him in himself, and will glorify him at once.
Little children, I am with you only a little longer. You will search for me, and just as I said to the Jews, 'Where I am going, you cannot come,' so now I say to you.
A new commandment I give to you: that you love one another. Just as I have loved you, so you also should love one another.
By this everyone will know that you are my disciples—if you have love for one another."
Simon Peter says to him, "Lord, where are you going?" Jesus answered, "Where I am going you cannot follow me now, but you will follow later."
Peter says to him, "Lord, why can't I follow you now? I will lay down my life for you."
Jesus answers, "Will you lay down your life for me? Truly, truly, I tell you: the rooster will not crow before you have denied me three times."

chapters.notes:
**"Loved them to the end" (v. 1)**: The phrase εἰς τέλος can mean either "to the end" (temporally—through to the conclusion) or "to the uttermost" (to the full extent). Both meanings resonate here: Jesus loved them through to the end of his life, and he loved them completely. "To the end" preserves the temporal sense while allowing the fuller meaning to echo, especially given what follows.

**"Not for all eternity" (v. 8)**: Peter's εἰς τὸν αἰῶνα is an emphatic negative construction—literally "into the age/eternity." This is stronger than a simple "never"; it expresses absolute, eternal refusal. The rendering captures Peter's characteristic hyperbole.

**"Have no share with me" (v. 8)**: The word μέρος means "part, portion, share"—particularly in the sense of participation or partnership. This is relational language about belonging, not merely about having something. Peter would have no place in Jesus's community.

**"The one who has bathed" (v. 10)**: The Greek distinguishes between λούω (to bathe the whole body) and νίπτω (to wash a part, here the feet). Jesus is drawing on the cultural practice: one bathed at home, then walked to dinner on dusty roads, requiring only foot-washing upon arrival. The spiritual metaphor is clear to the original audience.

**"One who is sent out" (v. 16)**: The term ἀπόστολος literally means "one sent out with a commission"—an envoy or emissary. Before becoming a technical term for the Twelve, it carried this general sense of authorized messenger. The translation preserves this meaning without imposing the later technical usage.

**"I AM" (v. 19)**: The phrase ἐγώ εἰμι echoes the divine self-identification from Exodus 3:14 and appears repeatedly in John's Gospel as a claim to divine identity. When used absolutely (without a predicate), as here, it carries this weight of divine self-disclosure. The capitalization signals this is not merely "I am he" but the divine Name.

**"Close beside Jesus" (v. 23)**: The phrase ἐν τῷ κόλπῳ ("in the bosom/chest") refers to the ancient practice of reclining at meals. Diners reclined on their left side, so the beloved disciple's position at Jesus's right meant his head was near Jesus's chest—the place of intimacy and honor.

**"Leaning back" (v. 25)**: The verb ἀναπίπτω means to fall or lean backward—here, the disciple shifts his position to speak privately with Jesus by leaning back against his chest.

**"It was night" (v. 30)**: While literally describing the time of day, John's Gospel consistently uses light and darkness symbolically. This simple statement carries ominous weight: Judas goes out into the darkness, both literally and spiritually.

**"Little children" (v. 33)**: The diminutive τεκνία expresses deep affection and intimacy—this is Jesus's only use of this tender address in John's Gospel, heightening the poignancy of the moment.

verses.text: Do not let your heart be troubled. You trust in God—trust also in me.
In my Father's house there are many dwelling places. If it were not so, would I have told you that I am going to prepare a place for you?
And if I go and prepare a place for you, I am coming again and will receive you to myself, so that where I am, you also may be.
And where I am going, you know the way.
Thomas said to him, "Lord, we do not know where you are going. How can we know the way?"
Jesus said to him, "I am the way and the truth and the life. No one comes to the Father except through me.
If you have come to know me, you will also know my Father. From this moment forward you know him and have seen him."
Philip said to him, "Lord, show us the Father, and that will be enough for us."
Jesus said to him, "Have I been with you for so long a time, and you have not come to know me, Philip? The one who has seen me has seen the Father. How can you say, 'Show us the Father'?
Do you not trust that I am in the Father and the Father is in me? The words that I speak to you I do not speak from myself, but the Father who remains in me does his works.
Trust me that I am in the Father and the Father is in me—or if not, trust because of the works themselves.
Truly, truly I tell you, the one who trusts in me will also do the works that I do, and will do greater works than these, because I am going to the Father.
And whatever you ask in my name, I will do it, so that the Father may be glorified in the Son.
If you ask me anything in my name, I will do it.
If you love me, you will keep my commandments.
And I will ask the Father, and he will give you another Advocate to be with you forever—
the Spirit of truth, whom the world cannot receive because it does not see him or know him. You know him, because he remains with you and will be in you.
I will not leave you orphaned. I am coming to you.
In just a little while the world will no longer see me, but you will see me. Because I live, you also will live.
On that day you will know that I am in my Father, and you are in me, and I am in you.
The one who has my commandments and keeps them—that one is the one who loves me. And the one who loves me will be loved by my Father, and I will love him and will reveal myself to him."
Judas (not Iscariot) said to him, "Lord, what has happened that you are about to reveal yourself to us and not to the world?"
Jesus answered and said to him, "If anyone loves me, he will keep my word, and my Father will love him, and we will come to him and make our dwelling place with him.
The one who does not love me does not keep my words. And the word that you hear is not mine but belongs to the Father who sent me.
These things I have spoken to you while remaining with you.
But the Advocate, the Holy Spirit whom the Father will send in my name—he will teach you all things and will remind you of everything I have said to you.
Peace I leave to you. My peace I give to you. Not as the world gives do I give to you. Do not let your heart be troubled, and do not let it be fearful.
You heard me say to you, 'I am going away and I am coming to you.' If you loved me, you would have rejoiced that I am going to the Father, because the Father is greater than I am.
And now I have told you before it happens, so that when it does happen you may trust.
I will no longer speak much with you, for the ruler of this world is coming. And he has no claim on me,
but so that the world may know that I love the Father, I do exactly as the Father has commanded me. Get up, let us go from here."

chapters.notes:
**"Trust" rather than "believe" (vv. 1, 10, 11, 12, 29)**: The Greek πιστεύω in Johannine literature carries more than intellectual assent—it implies personal reliance and commitment. "Trust" better captures this relational dimension, particularly in contexts like verse 1 where Jesus is addressing their troubled hearts, not their intellectual doubts.

**"Dwelling places" (v. 2) and "dwelling place" (v. 23)**: The Greek μονή means a place where one stays or abides. The traditional "mansions" (from Latin *mansiones*) misleads modern readers toward luxury estates. The term simply means rooms or quarters where one remains. The wordplay becomes significant in verse 23, where Jesus promises that he and the Father will make their μονή with the believer—using the same term from verse 2. This is about intimate presence, not real estate.

**"Advocate" (vv. 16, 26)**: The Greek παράκλητος is notoriously difficult to translate. It means one called alongside to help—a legal advocate, counselor, or helper. "Comforter" (KJV) is too narrow and somewhat archaic. "Helper" is too generic. "Advocate" captures the legal and supportive dimensions while remaining accessible. The term emphasizes active assistance and representation.

**"Remains/remaining" (vv. 10, 17, 25)**: The Greek μένω is a key Johannine term meaning to stay, abide, remain, dwell. It conveys permanence and intimate presence. I've varied between "remains" and "remaining" based on English syntax, but the underlying concept is consistent—ongoing, stable presence.

**"From this moment forward" (v. 7)**: The Greek ἀπ' ἄρτι marks a pivotal temporal shift—from this point on, things are different. It's more emphatic than a simple "now."

**"What has happened" (v. 22)**: The Greek τί γέγονεν (perfect tense) suggests Judas is asking about what circumstance or event has occurred to cause this change in Jesus's plans. He's puzzled about why the revelation will be limited rather than universal.

**"He has no claim on me" (v. 30)**: The Greek ἐν ἐμοὶ οὐκ ἔχει οὐδέν literally means "in me he has nothing." This is an idiomatic way of saying the ruler of this world has no hold, claim, or authority over Jesus—no ground to stand on, no legitimate charge or power.

**"Greater than I am" (v. 28)**: This statement has generated enormous theological discussion. The Greek ὁ πατὴρ μείζων μού ἐστιν is straightforward—within the narrative context of the incarnation and Jesus's impending return to the Father, this comparative makes sense without necessarily implying ontological subordination. The context is Jesus's going to the Father, which is cause for joy.

verses.text: I am the true vine, and my Father is the vinegrower.
Every branch in me that does not bear fruit, he removes; and every branch that does bear fruit, he prunes clean so that it may bear more fruit.
You are already clean because of the word I have spoken to you.
Remain in me, and I in you. Just as the branch cannot bear fruit by itself unless it remains in the vine, so neither can you unless you remain in me.
I am the vine; you are the branches. The one who remains in me and I in him—this one bears much fruit, because apart from me you can do nothing.
If anyone does not remain in me, he is thrown out like the branch and withers; and they gather them and throw them into the fire, and they are burned.
If you remain in me and my words remain in you, ask whatever you wish, and it will come to be for you.
In this my Father has been glorified: that you bear much fruit and so prove to be my disciples.
Just as the Father has loved me, so I have loved you. Remain in my love.
If you keep my commandments, you will remain in my love, just as I have kept my Father's commandments and remain in his love.
I have spoken these things to you so that my joy may be in you and your joy may be made full.
This is my commandment: that you love one another as I have loved you.
No one has greater love than this: that someone lay down his life for his friends.
You are my friends if you do what I command you.
I no longer call you servants, because the servant does not know what his master is doing. But I have called you friends, because everything I have heard from my Father I have made known to you.
You did not choose me, but I chose you and appointed you so that you would go and bear fruit, and that your fruit would remain, so that whatever you ask the Father in my name, he will give you.
These things I command you: that you love one another.
If the world hates you, understand that it has hated me before it hated you.
If you belonged to the world, the world would love what is its own. But because you do not belong to the world—rather, I chose you out of the world—for this reason the world hates you.
Remember the word that I spoke to you: 'A servant is not greater than his master.' If they persecuted me, they will persecute you also. If they kept my word, they will keep yours also.
But they will do all these things to you on account of my name, because they do not know the one who sent me.
If I had not come and spoken to them, they would not have sin. But now they have no excuse for their sin.
The one who hates me hates my Father also.
If I had not done among them the works that no one else has done, they would not have sin. But now they have both seen and hated both me and my Father.
But this is to fulfill the word that is written in their law: 'They hated me without cause.'
When the Advocate comes, whom I will send to you from the Father—the Spirit of truth who proceeds from the Father—that one will bear witness concerning me.
And you also bear witness, because you have been with me from the beginning.

chapters.notes:
**"Vinegrower" (v. 1)**: The Greek γεωργός literally means "earth-worker" or "farmer," but in the context of this extended vine metaphor, "vinegrower" (or "vine-dresser") more precisely captures the specialized agricultural role being described.

**"Removes" and "prunes clean" (v. 2)**: The Greek uses αἴρει (lifts up/takes away/removes) and καθαίρει (cleanses/prunes). There's wordplay here with "clean" (καθαροί) in verse 3. The vinegrower's pruning makes branches clean/pure for better fruitfulness. I've preserved the connection with "prunes clean."

**"Remain" (throughout)**: The Greek μένω/μείνατε appears repeatedly throughout this passage. While often translated "abide," the more natural English "remain" better captures the sense of continuing presence and connection. The repetition is deliberate and creates a structural rhythm that should be preserved.

**"Come to be" (v. 7)**: The Greek γενήσεται is simply "it will be/become/happen," emphasizing realization rather than mere receiving.

**"Prove to be" (v. 8)**: The Greek γένησθε with the verb "become" suggests demonstrating or proving one's identity as disciples through bearing fruit, not merely being identified as such.

**"Lay down his life" (v. 13)**: The Greek τὴν ψυχὴν αὐτοῦ θῇ literally means "lay down his soul/life." The word ψυχή encompasses both physical life and the animating principle of a person.

**"Appointed" (v. 16)**: The Greek ἔθηκα literally means "placed" or "set," but in this context of divine commission, "appointed" better captures the authoritative assignment to a role and purpose.

**"Belonged to" (v. 19)**: The Greek ἐκ τοῦ κόσμου ἦτε literally means "you were from/of the world." I've used "belonged to" to capture the sense of origin and allegiance that ἐκ conveys here.

**"Advocate" (v. 26)**: The Greek παράκλητος is a rich legal and social term meaning one called alongside to help—an advocate, counselor, helper, or comforter. In the Johannine context, this is a forensic figure who testifies and defends. "Advocate" captures the legal dimension while remaining accessible. The traditional "Comforter" is too narrow; "Helper" too generic; "Counselor" misses the forensic context.

**"Proceeds from" (v. 26)**: The Greek ἐκπορεύεται has theological significance in later Trinitarian debates. It means "goes out from" or "proceeds from," indicating the Spirit's origin or mission from the Father.

**"Without cause" (v. 25)**: The Greek δωρεάν means "freely, as a gift, gratuitously"—here in the negative sense of "without reason or justification." This quotes Psalm 69:4 (LXX 68:5) or Psalm 35:19.

verses.text: I have spoken these things to you so that you will not fall away.
They will expel you from the synagogues. Indeed, an hour is coming when everyone who kills you will think they are offering sacred service to God.
And they will do these things because they have not known the Father or me.
But I have spoken these things to you so that when their hour comes, you may remember that I told you about them. I did not tell you these things from the beginning, because I was with you.
But now I am going to the one who sent me, and not one of you asks me, "Where are you going?"
Rather, because I have spoken these things to you, grief has filled your heart.
But I tell you the truth: it is to your advantage that I go away. For if I do not go away, the Advocate will not come to you; but if I go, I will send him to you.
And when he comes, he will expose the world concerning sin, and concerning righteousness, and concerning judgment:
concerning sin, because they do not believe in me;
concerning righteousness, because I am going to the Father and you will no longer see me;
and concerning judgment, because the ruler of this world has been judged.
I still have many things to say to you, but you cannot bear them now.

But when he comes—that one, the Spirit of truth—he will guide you into all the truth. For he will not speak from himself, but whatever he hears he will speak, and he will announce to you the things that are coming.
He will glorify me, because he will take from what is mine and announce it to you.
Everything that the Father has is mine. This is why I said that he takes from what is mine and will announce it to you.
A little while and you will no longer see me, and again a little while and you will see me.

So some of his disciples said to one another, "What does this mean that he is saying to us: 'A little while and you do not see me, and again a little while and you will see me,' and, 'Because I am going to the Father'?"
They were saying, "What is this 'little while' he is talking about? We do not know what he is saying."

Jesus knew that they wanted to question him, and he said to them, "Are you inquiring among yourselves about this—that I said, 'A little while and you do not see me, and again a little while and you will see me'?
Amen, amen, I tell you: you will weep and lament, but the world will rejoice. You will be grieved, but your grief will become joy.

A woman, when she is giving birth, has grief because her hour has come. But when she has delivered the child, she no longer remembers the anguish because of the joy that a human being has been born into the world.
So you also now have grief. But I will see you again, and your heart will rejoice, and no one will take your joy from you.
And on that day you will not ask me anything. Amen, amen, I tell you: whatever you ask the Father, he will give you in my name.
Until now you have asked for nothing in my name. Ask, and you will receive, so that your joy may be complete.
I have spoken these things to you in figures of speech. An hour is coming when I will no longer speak to you in figures of speech, but I will announce to you plainly about the Father.
On that day you will ask in my name, and I do not tell you that I will petition the Father on your behalf,
for the Father himself loves you, because you have loved me and have believed that I came forth from God.
I came forth from the Father and have come into the world. Again, I am leaving the world and going to the Father.
His disciples said, "Look, now you are speaking plainly and not using any figure of speech.
Now we know that you know all things and have no need for anyone to question you. By this we believe that you came forth from God."
Jesus answered them, "Do you believe now?
Look, an hour is coming—and has come—when you will be scattered, each to his own, and you will leave me alone. Yet I am not alone, because the Father is with me.
I have spoken these things to you so that in me you may have peace. In the world you have affliction, but take courage: I have conquered the world."

chapters.notes:
**"Fall away" (v. 1)**: The Greek σκανδαλισθῆτε carries the sense of being trapped or caused to stumble, leading to apostasy. "Fall away" captures this meaning of abandoning faith under pressure.

**"Sacred service" (v. 2)**: The Greek λατρείαν refers specifically to religious worship or cultic service. The point is that persecutors will believe their violence is an act of devotion to God—a chilling warning about religious zeal divorced from true knowledge.

**"The Advocate" (v. 7)**: The Greek παράκλητος is a technical legal and forensic term meaning one called alongside to help—an advocate, counselor, or defender. The traditional "Comforter" (from Latin *confortare*, to strengthen) captures only part of the meaning. "Helper" is too weak. "Advocate" better conveys the legal and defensive role this figure plays in the following verses.

**"Expose" (v. 8)**: The Greek ἐλέγξει means to expose, convict, or bring to light—particularly in a legal sense. It's stronger than merely "convict" (internal) or "prove wrong" (intellectual). The Spirit will lay bare the truth about these matters before the world.

**"Guide you into all the truth" (v. 13)**: The Greek ὁδηγήσει ὑμᾶς ἐν τῇ ἀληθείᾳ πάσῃ literally means "guide you in all the truth" (with a locative sense of being within truth's realm). The Spirit leads disciples deeper into truth's territory, not just to a single doctrinal destination.

**"Bear" (v. 12)**: The Greek βαστάζειν means to carry, bear the weight of. The disciples cannot yet carry the full weight of what Jesus wants to teach them.

**"Figures of speech" (v. 25, 29)**: The Greek παροιμίαις refers to figurative or veiled speech—proverbs, riddles, indirect sayings. "Plainly" translates παρρησίᾳ, which means open, frank, bold speech without concealment.

**"Complete" (v. 24)**: The Greek πεπληρωμένη means filled full, made complete. Their joy will reach its intended fullness.

**"Conquered" (v. 33)**: The Greek νενίκηκα is a perfect tense verb meaning "I have conquered" or "I have overcome." The victory is already accomplished, though its effects continue. Jesus speaks from the vantage point of completed triumph.

verses.text: Jesus said these things, and lifting his eyes toward heaven, he said: "Father, the hour has come. Glorify your Son, so that the Son may glorify you,
just as you gave him authority over all flesh, so that to all whom you have given him, he may give eternal life.
And this is eternal life: that they may know you, the only true God, and Jesus Christ whom you sent.
I glorified you on the earth, having completed the work that you gave me to do.
And now, Father, glorify me in your own presence with the glory that I had in your presence before the world existed.
I have made your name known to the people whom you gave me out of the world. They were yours, and you gave them to me, and they have kept your word.
Now they have come to know that everything you have given me is from you,
because the words that you gave me I have given to them, and they received them and truly knew that I came forth from you, and they believed that you sent me.
I am asking on their behalf. I am not asking on behalf of the world, but on behalf of those whom you have given me, because they are yours.
And all that is mine is yours, and what is yours is mine, and I have been glorified in them.
And I am no longer in the world, yet they are in the world, and I am coming to you. Holy Father, keep them in your name that you have given me, so that they may be one just as we are one.
When I was with them, I kept them in your name that you have given me. I guarded them, and not one of them was lost except the son of destruction, so that the scripture might be fulfilled.
But now I am coming to you, and I speak these things in the world so that they may have my joy brought to completion in themselves.
I have given them your word, and the world has hated them because they are not from the world, just as I am not from the world.
I am not asking that you take them out of the world, but that you keep them from the evil one.
They are not from the world, just as I am not from the world.
Consecrate them in the truth; your word is truth.
Just as you sent me into the world, so I have sent them into the world.
And on their behalf I consecrate myself, so that they also may be consecrated in truth.
I am asking not only on behalf of these, but also on behalf of those who believe in me through their word,
so that all may be one. Just as you, Father, are in me and I am in you, may they also be in us, so that the world may believe that you sent me.
And the glory that you have given me I have given to them, so that they may be one just as we are one,
I in them and you in me, so that they may be perfected into one, so that the world may know that you sent me and loved them just as you loved me.

Father, as for what you have given me, I desire that where I am, they also may be with me, so that they may behold my glory that you have given me, because you loved me before the foundation of the world.
Righteous Father, the world did not know you, but I knew you, and these have come to know that you sent me.
And I made your name known to them, and I will make it known, so that the love with which you loved me may be in them, and I in them."

chapters.notes:
**"Authority over all flesh" (v. 2)**: The Greek πάσης σαρκός literally means "all flesh"—a Hebraism referring to all humanity, not just physical bodies. This echoes Old Testament usage where "all flesh" denotes all people (e.g., Genesis 6:12, Isaiah 40:5-6).

**"Eternal life" (v. 2-3)**: The Greek ζωὴν αἰώνιον means life of the age to come—not merely unending duration but the quality of life characteristic of God's eternal realm. The immediate definition provided in verse 3 (knowing God) emphasizes relationship over mere temporal extension.

**"Made your name known / made known" (v. 6, 26)**: The Greek ἐφανέρωσα and ἐγνώρισα mean to reveal, manifest, or make known. In Hebrew thought, God's "name" represents his character, nature, and presence—not merely a designation. Jesus reveals who God truly is.

**"Keep them / kept them / guarded them" (v. 11-12)**: The Greek τηρέω means to guard, protect, preserve, keep safe. It appears repeatedly in this prayer with different nuances—sometimes keeping in safety, sometimes keeping in faithfulness to God's name or word.

**"The son of destruction" (v. 12)**: A Hebrew idiom where "son of X" means one characterized by or destined for X. The Greek ὁ υἱὸς τῆς ἀπωλείας refers to Judas as one destined for or characterized by destruction/perdition.

**"Consecrate / consecrated / consecrate myself" (v. 17, 19)**: The Greek ἁγιάζω means to make holy, set apart for sacred purpose. "Sanctify" is traditional but increasingly archaic. "Consecrate" better captures the sense of being dedicated or set apart for God's purposes. In verse 19, Jesus consecrates himself—sets himself apart for the sacrificial purpose of the cross.

**"The evil one" (v. 15)**: The Greek τοῦ πονηροῦ can be either neuter ("evil" as an abstract) or masculine ("the evil one" as a personal being). Given Johannine theology's emphasis on personal cosmic conflict (the ruler of this world, the devil, Satan), the personal rendering is more likely.

**"Perfected into one" (v. 23)**: The Greek τετελειωμένοι εἰς ἕν uses a perfect participle suggesting completion or maturity brought to fullness. "Perfected" preserves both the sense of completion and the intensification of unity—not just "being" one but being brought to complete/mature oneness.

**"Behold" (v. 24)**: The Greek θεωρῶσιν means more than casual seeing—it implies contemplative viewing, sustained observation, or beholding with understanding. It's the root of our word "theory" (contemplation of truth).

**"Before the foundation of the world" (v. 24)**: The Greek πρὸ καταβολῆς κόσμου is a technical phrase meaning before creation's beginning. Καταβολή literally means "laying down" or "founding," hence "foundation."

**Repetition of "you sent me"**: This phrase (σύ με ἀπέστειλας) appears repeatedly (vv. 3, 8, 18, 21, 23, 25) as a central theme. The consistency has been preserved to maintain the rhetorical emphasis on Jesus's mission as rooted in the Father's sending.

verses.text: After saying these things, Jesus went out with his disciples across the Kidron ravine, where there was a garden, and he and his disciples entered it.
Now Judas, who was betraying him, also knew the place, because Jesus had often gathered there with his disciples.
So Judas, having received the cohort and officers from the chief priests and from the Pharisees, comes there with torches, lanterns, and weapons.
Then Jesus, knowing everything that was coming upon him, went out and says to them, "Who are you looking for?"
They answered him, "Jesus the Nazorean." He says to them, "I am." Now Judas, who was betraying him, was also standing with them.
So when he said to them, "I am," they drew back and fell to the ground.
Again, then, he asked them, "Who are you looking for?" And they said, "Jesus the Nazorean."
Jesus answered, "I told you that I am. So if you are looking for me, let these men go"—
so that the word he had spoken might be fulfilled: "Of those you have given me, I have not lost a single one of them."
Then Simon Peter, who had a sword, drew it and struck the high priest's slave and cut off his right ear. The slave's name was Malchus.
So Jesus said to Peter, "Put the sword into its sheath. The cup that the Father has given me—shall I not drink it?"
Then the cohort, the tribune, and the officers of the Jews seized Jesus and bound him,
and they led him first to Annas, for he was the father-in-law of Caiaphas, who was high priest that year.
Now Caiaphas was the one who had advised the Jews that it was expedient for one man to die on behalf of the people.
Simon Peter was following Jesus, and so was another disciple. That disciple was known to the high priest and entered with Jesus into the high priest's courtyard,
but Peter was standing outside at the door. So the other disciple, the one known to the high priest, went out and spoke to the doorkeeper and brought Peter in.
Then the servant-girl who was the doorkeeper says to Peter, "You're not also one of this man's disciples, are you?" He says, "I am not."
Now the slaves and the officers were standing around a charcoal fire they had made, because it was cold, and they were warming themselves. Peter was also with them, standing and warming himself.
The high priest then questioned Jesus about his disciples and about his teaching.
Jesus answered him, "I have spoken openly to the world. I have always taught in synagogue and in the temple, where all the Jews gather together, and I have said nothing in secret.
Why do you question me? Question those who have heard what I said to them. Look—these people know what I said."
When he said these things, one of the officers standing nearby gave Jesus a slap, saying, "Is this how you answer the high priest?"
Jesus answered him, "If I have spoken wrongly, testify about what is wrong. But if I have spoken rightly, why do you strike me?"
Then Annas sent him, still bound, to Caiaphas the high priest.
Now Simon Peter was standing and warming himself. So they said to him, "You're not also one of his disciples, are you?" He denied it and said, "I am not."
One of the high priest's slaves, a relative of the man whose ear Peter had cut off, says, "Didn't I see you in the garden with him?"
Again, then, Peter denied it, and immediately a rooster crowed.
Then they lead Jesus from Caiaphas to the praetorium. It was early morning. They themselves did not enter the praetorium, so that they would not be defiled but could eat the Passover.
So Pilate came out to them and says, "What accusation do you bring against this man?"
They answered and said to him, "If this man were not doing evil, we would not have handed him over to you."
Then Pilate said to them, "Take him yourselves and judge him according to your law." The Jews said to him, "It is not lawful for us to execute anyone"—
so that the word of Jesus might be fulfilled that he had spoken, indicating by what kind of death he was going to die.
So Pilate entered the praetorium again and summoned Jesus and said to him, "Are you the King of the Jews?"
Jesus answered, "Are you saying this on your own, or did others tell you about me?"
Pilate answered, "I'm not a Jew, am I? Your own nation and the chief priests handed you over to me. What have you done?"

Jesus answered, "My kingdom is not from this world. If my kingdom were from this world, my servants would have been fighting to prevent me from being handed over to the Jews. But as it is, my kingdom is not from here."

Then Pilate said to him, "So you are a king?" Jesus answered, "You say that I am a king. For this I was born, and for this I have come into the world: to bear witness to the truth. Everyone who is from the truth hears my voice."
Pilate says to him, "What is truth?" After saying this, he went out again to the Jews and says to them, "I find no case against him.
But you have a custom that I release one man for you at the Passover. So do you want me to release for you the King of the Jews?"
Then they shouted back, saying, "Not this man, but Barabbas!" Now Barabbas was a bandit.

chapters.notes:
**"Kidron ravine" (v. 1)**: The Greek χείμαρρος refers specifically to a wadi or ravine that flows with winter rains but is often dry. "Brook" or "stream" (common in traditional translations) misses this seasonal character. The Kidron is a ravine east of Jerusalem.

**"I am" (vv. 5, 6, 8)**: The Greek ἐγώ εἰμι carries deliberate theological weight in John's Gospel, echoing the divine name from Exodus 3:14 (LXX). The dramatic response in v. 6—falling to the ground—suggests the recognition of divine presence. While "It is I" is grammatically possible, the absolute "I am" preserves the echo of divine self-identification that John's first audience would have heard.

**"Cohort" (vv. 3, 12)**: The Greek σπεῖρα is a Roman military term for a cohort, normally 600 soldiers (or more loosely, a detachment). This is not a small arresting party but a significant military force, emphasizing the perceived threat Jesus posed.

**"Tribune" (v. 12)**: The χιλίαρχος is the Roman military officer commanding a cohort, typically translated "commander" or "captain," but "tribune" is the more precise technical term.

**"Nazorean" (vv. 5, 7)**: The Greek Ναζωραῖος is rendered here as "Nazorean" rather than "Nazarene" to preserve its more formal, possibly titular quality in John's usage (as opposed to the more common Ναζαρηνός).

**"The word he had spoken" (v. 9)**: John refers back to Jesus's prayer in 17:12. This is an internal fulfillment within the Gospel narrative itself, not a citation of Hebrew Scripture.

**"Expedient" (v. 14)**: The Greek συμφέρει means "it is advantageous, expedient, beneficial"—a calculated political judgment, not a moral or theological necessity. This preserves Caiaphas's pragmatic reasoning (see 11:50).

**"Servant-girl who was the doorkeeper" (v. 17)**: The Greek παιδίσκη ἡ θυρωρός specifies both her gender (female servant) and role (doorkeeper/gatekeeper). This detail matters for the narrative—Peter is challenged by someone of low social status.

**"Praetorium" (vv. 28, 33)**: The Greek πραιτώριον (Latin loanword) refers to the Roman governor's headquarters/residence. Left untranslated as a technical term, like other Roman administrative vocabulary.

**"So that they would not be defiled" (v. 28)**: The concern is ritual purity to eat the Passover meal. Entering a Gentile residence would convey impurity. John's chronology places Jesus's crucifixion on the day of Passover preparation, when the lambs were slaughtered—making Jesus the Passover lamb.

**"Are you saying this on your own" (v. 34)**: Literally "from yourself"—Jesus asks whether Pilate's question originates from his own assessment or from what he has been told by the Jewish authorities.

**"From this world" / "from here" (v. 36)**: The Greek ἐκ with genitive indicates origin or source. Jesus's kingdom has a different origin than earthly political kingdoms—it does not derive its nature or authority from the present world system.

**"You say that I am a king" (v. 37)**: This can be understood as affirmation ("You are correct in saying...") rather than evasion. The following sentence confirms Jesus's kingship but redefines it in terms of witness to truth.

**"Bandit" (v. 40)**: The Greek λῃστής can mean robber, bandit, or revolutionary/insurrectionist. Given the Roman context and Pilate's involvement, Barabbas was likely involved in violent resistance against Rome—more than a mere thief.

verses.text: Then Pilate took Jesus and had him flogged.
The soldiers wove a crown out of thorns and placed it on his head, and they threw a purple robe around him.
They kept coming up to him and saying, "Hail, King of the Jews!"—and they struck him with their hands.
Pilate came out again and said to them, "Look, I am bringing him out to you so that you may know I find no basis for a charge against him."
So Jesus came out, wearing the thorn crown and the purple robe. And Pilate said to them, "Look—the man!"
When the chief priests and the temple guards saw him, they shouted, "Crucify him! Crucify him!" Pilate said to them, "You take him and crucify him. I find no basis for a charge against him."
The Judean authorities answered him, "We have a law, and according to that law he must die, because he made himself the Son of God."
When Pilate heard this statement, he became even more afraid.
He went back into the praetorium and said to Jesus, "Where are you from?" But Jesus gave him no answer.
So Pilate said to him, "You will not speak to me? Do you not know that I have authority to release you and I have authority to crucify you?"
Jesus answered, "You would have no authority over me at all unless it had been given to you from above. Therefore the one who handed me over to you has the greater sin."

From that moment on, Pilate kept trying to release him. But the Judean authorities shouted, "If you release this man, you are no friend of Caesar! Everyone who makes himself a king sets himself against Caesar!"
When Pilate heard these words, he brought Jesus outside and sat down on the judgment seat at a place called the Stone Pavement—in Hebrew, Gabbatha.
It was the day of Preparation for Passover, about the sixth hour. He said to the Judeans, "Look—your king!"
They shouted back, "Away with him! Away with him! Crucify him!" Pilate said to them, "Should I crucify your king?" The chief priests answered, "We have no king but Caesar!"
So then he handed him over to them to be crucified. They took Jesus,
and carrying the cross for himself, he went out to what is called the Place of the Skull, which in Hebrew is called Golgotha.
There they crucified him, and with him two others—one on each side, with Jesus in the middle.
Pilate also had an inscription written and placed on the cross. It read: "Jesus the Nazorean, the King of the Judeans."
Many of the Judeans read this inscription, because the place where Jesus was crucified was near the city, and it was written in Hebrew, in Latin, and in Greek.
So the chief priests of the Judeans said to Pilate, "Do not write 'The King of the Judeans,' but rather 'This man said, I am King of the Judeans.'"
Pilate answered, "What I have written, I have written."

When the soldiers crucified Jesus, they took his clothing and divided it into four shares, one share for each soldier. They also took the tunic, but the tunic was seamless, woven in one piece from top to bottom.

So they said to one another, "Let us not tear it, but cast lots for it to see who will get it"—so that the scripture might be fulfilled that says, *They divided my garments among themselves, and for my clothing they cast lots.* This is what the soldiers did.
Standing near the cross of Jesus were his mother, his mother's sister, Mary the wife of Clopas, and Mary Magdalene.
When Jesus saw his mother and the disciple whom he loved standing nearby, he said to his mother, "Woman, look—your son."
Then he said to the disciple, "Look—your mother." And from that hour the disciple took her into his own home.
After this, Jesus, knowing that everything was now completed in order that the scripture might be brought to its fulfillment, said, "I thirst."
A jar full of sour wine was standing there, so they put a sponge soaked with the sour wine on a hyssop branch and brought it to his mouth.
When Jesus had received the sour wine, he said, "It is completed." And he bowed his head and gave up his spirit.

Since it was the day of Preparation, the Judean authorities asked Pilate to have the legs broken and the bodies taken down, so that the bodies would not remain on the cross during the Sabbath—for that Sabbath was a high day.
So the soldiers came and broke the legs of the first man and of the other who had been crucified with him.
But when they came to Jesus and saw that he was already dead, they did not break his legs.
Instead, one of the soldiers pierced his side with a spear, and immediately blood and water came out.
The one who saw this has testified, and his testimony is true, and he knows that he speaks the truth, so that you also may believe.
For these things happened so that the scripture would be fulfilled: *Not one of his bones shall be broken.*
And again another scripture says, *They shall look on the one whom they have pierced.*

After these things, Joseph from Arimathea, who was a disciple of Jesus but secretly because of his fear of the Judean authorities, asked Pilate if he could take away the body of Jesus. Pilate gave permission, so he came and took his body.
Nicodemus also came—the one who had first come to him at night—bringing a mixture of myrrh and aloes, about a hundred pounds.
So they took the body of Jesus and wrapped it in linen cloths with the spices, according to the burial custom of the Judeans.
Now in the place where he was crucified there was a garden, and in the garden a new tomb in which no one had ever been laid.
So because it was the Judean day of Preparation, and because the tomb was nearby, they laid Jesus there.

chapters.notes:
**"The Judeans" vs. "the Jews"**: The Greek Ἰουδαῖοι presents a well-known translation challenge. In John's Gospel, it often refers not to Jewish people generally but to the Judean religious authorities (centered in Jerusalem) who oppose Jesus. "Judeans" preserves both the geographical specificity and the institutional power dynamics. Where the term clearly means ethnic/religious identity broadly (as in v. 40, "burial custom"), "Judean" still works since Jesus himself was Judean/Jewish. The alternative "the Jews" is both anachronistic (Judaism as we know it post-dates the Second Temple period) and has contributed to centuries of anti-Semitism.

**"The Nazorean" (v. 19)**: Ναζωραῖος rather than the more common Ναζαρηνός. Both mean "from Nazareth," but Nazorean is the specific form Pilate's inscription uses. The distinction may reflect official Roman nomenclature.

**"It is completed" (v. 30)**: Τετέλεσται is the perfect tense of τελέω—to complete, to accomplish, to bring to fulfillment. This is not merely "it is finished" in the sense of being over, but rather "it has been accomplished/brought to completion." The perfect tense emphasizes the completed state with ongoing significance. This saying echoes the language of v. 28 (τετέλεσται/τελειωθῇ) and frames Jesus's death as the completion of his mission and the fulfillment of scripture.

**"Gave up his spirit" (v. 30)**: παρέδωκεν τὸ πνεῦμα could be rendered "handed over the spirit" or "delivered up the spirit." The verb παραδίδωμι (to hand over, deliver, betray) has been used throughout the passion narrative for Judas's betrayal and the handing over of Jesus to the authorities. Here Jesus himself actively "hands over" his spirit—a final sovereign act.

**"The sixth hour" (v. 14)**: This is approximately noon by Roman reckoning (counting from midnight), though some scholars suggest John uses Jewish reckoning (from dawn), which would make it around 6 AM. The chronology differs from the Synoptic accounts. I've left it as "sixth hour" to preserve the ambiguity in the original.

**"High day" (v. 31)**: μεγάλη ἡ ἡμέρα—literally "that day was great." This Sabbath was particularly significant because it coincided with Passover.

**"Hyssop" (v. 29)**: ὑσσώπῳ. This is likely an allusion to Exodus 12:22, where hyssop is used to apply the Passover lamb's blood to the doorposts. John presents Jesus as the true Passover lamb throughout this Gospel.

**"One of his bones shall be broken" (v. 36)**: This fulfills both Exodus 12:46 (Passover lamb regulation) and Psalm 34:20. John consistently presents Jesus as the Passover lamb whose sacrifice brings deliverance.

**"They shall look on the one whom they have pierced" (v. 37)**: From Zechariah 12:10. The verb ἐξεκέντησαν specifically means to pierce through, matching the spear thrust of v. 34.

**"A hundred pounds" (v. 39)**: λίτρας ἑκατόν—about 75 pounds in modern measurement. This is an extraordinary amount of spices, fitting for a royal burial and signaling Jesus's true kingship.

verses.text: On the first day of the week, Mary the Magdalene comes to the tomb early while it was still dark, and she sees the stone having been removed from the tomb.
So she runs and comes to Simon Peter and to the other disciple whom Jesus loved, and says to them, "They have taken the Lord out of the tomb, and we do not know where they have laid him."
So Peter and the other disciple went out and were making their way toward the tomb.
The two were running together, but the other disciple ran ahead faster than Peter and arrived at the tomb first.
And stooping to look in, he sees the linen cloths lying there, but he did not go in.
Then Simon Peter also comes, following him, and he entered into the tomb. And he observes the linen cloths lying there,
and the face cloth, which had been on his head, not lying with the linen cloths but rolled up in a place by itself.
Then the other disciple, who had arrived at the tomb first, also entered, and he saw and believed.
For they did not yet understand the scripture, that it was necessary for him to rise from the dead.
So the disciples went back home again.
But Mary stood outside the tomb weeping. As she wept, she stooped to look into the tomb,
and she observes two angels in white, seated one at the head and one at the feet where the body of Jesus had been lying.
And they say to her, "Woman, why are you weeping?" She says to them, "They have taken my Lord, and I do not know where they have laid him."
Having said these things, she turned back around and observes Jesus standing there, but she did not know that it was Jesus.

Jesus says to her, "Woman, why are you weeping? Whom are you seeking?" She, supposing that he is the gardener, says to him, "Sir, if you are the one who carried him away, tell me where you have laid him, and I will take him away."
Jesus says to her, "Mary." Turning, she says to him in Hebrew, "Rabbouni"—which means Teacher.
Jesus says to her, "Do not cling to me, for I have not yet ascended to the Father. But go to my brothers and tell them: 'I am ascending to my Father and your Father, and my God and your God.'"
Mary the Magdalene comes announcing to the disciples, "I have seen the Lord," and that he had said these things to her.

When it was evening on that day, the first day of the week, and the doors having been locked where the disciples were because of fear of the Jewish authorities, Jesus came and stood in their midst and says to them, "Peace to you."
And having said this, he showed them his hands and his side. So the disciples rejoiced when they saw the Lord.
Jesus said to them again, "Peace to you. Just as the Father has sent me, so I am sending you."
And having said this, he breathed on them and says to them, "Receive the Holy Spirit.
If you forgive the sins of any, they have been forgiven them. If you retain the sins of any, they have been retained."
Now Thomas, one of the twelve, who is called the Twin, was not with them when Jesus came.

So the other disciples were saying to him, "We have seen the Lord." But he said to them, "Unless I see in his hands the mark of the nails, and put my finger into the mark of the nails, and put my hand into his side, I will never believe."
And after eight days, his disciples were inside again, and Thomas was with them. Jesus comes, the doors having been locked, and stood in their midst and said, "Peace to you."
Then he says to Thomas, "Bring your finger here and see my hands, and bring your hand and put it into my side, and do not become unbelieving but believing."
Thomas answered and said to him, "My Lord and my God!"
Jesus says to him, "Because you have seen me, you have believed? Blessed are those who have not seen and yet have believed."
Now Jesus did many other signs in the presence of the disciples, which are not written in this book.
But these have been written so that you may believe that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God, and so that by believing you may have life in his name.

chapters.notes:
**"The first day of the week" (v. 1, 19)**: The Greek τῇ μιᾷ τῶν σαββάτων is literally "on the one of the sabbaths," a Semitic idiom for the first day of the week (Sunday). I've rendered it idiomatically in English.

**"The other disciple whom Jesus loved" (v. 2)**: The verb φιλέω here denotes affectionate friendship, distinct from ἀγαπάω (though John uses both). I've rendered it as "loved" to match English conventions, though "held dear" captures the warmth of φιλέω.

**"We do not know" (v. 2)**: Mary uses the plural "we," though she apparently came alone. This may reflect her speaking for the larger community of disciples, or it may be a colloquial use of the plural.

**"Observes" vs. "sees" (various verses)**: I've distinguished between βλέπω (simple seeing) and θεωρέω (observing, examining closely). In verse 6, Peter "observes" (θεωρεῖ) the cloths, suggesting careful examination. In verse 8, the beloved disciple "saw" (εἶδεν, from ὁράω) and believed—a perception that goes beyond physical sight.

**"Do not cling to me" (v. 17)**: The Greek μή μου ἅπτου is a present imperative with negative particle, typically meaning "stop doing something already in progress." Mary is already touching or holding Jesus, and he tells her to stop. The verb ἅπτομαι can mean simply "touch," but the present tense suggests a continuing action—she is holding on to him. "Cling" captures this better than the traditional "touch."

**"I have not yet ascended" (v. 17)**: The Greek ἀναβέβηκα is perfect tense, emphasizing the completed state. Jesus hasn't yet completed his ascension to the Father, which explains why Mary should not cling to him—this is not the final reunion but a transitional moment.

**"The Jewish authorities" (v. 19)**: The Greek τῶν Ἰουδαίων literally means "the Jews," but in John's Gospel this phrase typically refers to the religious leadership hostile to Jesus, not to Jewish people generally (since Jesus and all his disciples were themselves Jewish). Given the historical misuse of this phrase to fuel antisemitism, "the Jewish authorities" clarifies John's meaning for modern readers without distorting the text.

**"The Twin" (v. 24)**: Δίδυμος is the Greek word for twin. The Aramaic "Thomas" (תאומא) also means twin, so this is actually a translation within the text: "Thomas, who is called 'the Twin' (in Greek)."

**"You have believed?" (v. 29)**: I've rendered this as a question following the most natural reading of the Greek syntax. Jesus is gently challenging Thomas: his belief came through seeing. The blessing that follows honors those who believe without such evidence.

**"So that you may believe" (v. 31)**: Some manuscripts read the aorist subjunctive πιστεύσητε (come to believe), others the present subjunctive πιστεύητε (continue believing). The SBLGNT follows the present, suggesting the text addresses those already within the community, encouraging ongoing faith. Either way, the purpose of the Gospel is clearly evangelistic and pastoral.

verses.text: After these things, Jesus revealed himself again to the disciples at the Sea of Tiberias. This is how he revealed himself:
Simon Peter, Thomas called the Twin, Nathanael from Cana in Galilee, the sons of Zebedee, and two others of his disciples were together.
Simon Peter said to them, "I'm going fishing." They said to him, "We're coming with you too." They went out and got into the boat, and that night they caught nothing.
Just as dawn was breaking, Jesus stood on the shore—though the disciples did not know that it was Jesus.
So Jesus said to them, "Children, you don't have any fish to eat, do you?" They answered him, "No."
He said to them, "Cast the net on the right side of the boat, and you will find some." So they cast it, and they no longer had strength to haul it in because of the multitude of fish.

Then that disciple whom Jesus loved said to Peter, "It is the Lord!" When Simon Peter heard that it was the Lord, he wrapped his outer garment around himself—for he was stripped down—and threw himself into the sea.
The other disciples came in the small boat, dragging the net full of fish, for they were not far from the land, only about two hundred cubits.
When they climbed out onto the land, they saw a charcoal fire laid there, with fish laid on it, and bread.
Jesus said to them, "Bring some of the fish you have just caught."
Simon Peter went up and dragged the net onto the land, full of large fish—one hundred fifty-three of them. And even though there were so many, the net was not torn.
Jesus said to them, "Come, have breakfast." None of the disciples dared to question him, "Who are you?"—knowing that it was the Lord.
Jesus came and took the bread and gave it to them, and the fish likewise.
This was now the third time Jesus revealed himself to the disciples after being raised from the dead.

When they had finished breakfast, Jesus said to Simon Peter, "Simon son of John, do you love me more than these?" He said to him, "Yes, Lord, you know that I love you." He said to him, "Feed my lambs."
He said to him a second time, "Simon son of John, do you love me?" He said to him, "Yes, Lord, you know that I love you." He said to him, "Shepherd my sheep."

He said to him the third time, "Simon son of John, do you love me?" Peter was grieved that he said to him the third time, "Do you love me?" And he said to him, "Lord, you know all things; you understand that I love me." Jesus said to him, "Feed my sheep.

Truly, truly I tell you: when you were younger, you fastened your own belt and walked wherever you wished. But when you grow old, you will stretch out your hands, and another will fasten your belt and carry you where you do not wish."
Now he said this to indicate by what kind of death he would glorify God. And having said this, he said to him, "Follow me."
Peter turned and saw the disciple whom Jesus loved following—the one who had reclined against his chest at the supper and had said, "Lord, who is the one betraying you?"
Seeing him, Peter said to Jesus, "Lord, what about this man?"
Jesus said to him, "If I want him to remain until I come, what is that to you? You follow me."
So this word went out among the brothers that that disciple would not die. Yet Jesus did not say to him that he would not die, but rather, "If I want him to remain until I come, what is that to you?"
This is the disciple who is bearing witness about these things and who wrote these things, and we know that his witness is true.
But there are also many other things that Jesus did, which if they were written down one by one, I do not think the world itself could contain the books that would be written.

chapters.notes:
**"Children" (v. 5)**: The Greek παιδία is a term of affection—not "boys" or diminutive in a condescending sense, but warm and familial. Jesus addresses them as a parent or teacher might address beloved young people.

**"Fish to eat" (v. 5)**: The Greek προσφάγιον specifically means something eaten with bread—typically fish. The question is not merely "do you have fish?" but "do you have any food/fish?"—reflecting the post-fishing expectation of having something to eat. This is more colloquial than "have you caught anything?"

**"Stripped down" (v. 7)**: The Greek γυμνός doesn't mean completely naked but rather minimally clothed for work—likely wearing only an undergarment. Peter puts on his outer garment (ἐπενδύτην) before jumping into the water, which would have been the culturally appropriate thing to do before greeting the Lord.

**"Two hundred cubits" (v. 8)**: About 100 yards or 90 meters—a short distance from shore.

**"Charcoal fire" (v. 9)**: The Greek ἀνθρακιάν is specific—a charcoal fire, not just any fire. This is the only other place in the New Testament besides John 18:18 where this word appears (where Peter was warming himself and denying Jesus). The echo would have been clear to the original audience.

**Love terminology (vv. 15-17)**: The Greek alternates between ἀγαπάω (vv. 15-16, Jesus's question) and φιλέω (Peter's response in all three, and Jesus's third question). Much has been made of this distinction, but in Koine Greek and especially in Johannine usage, these terms substantially overlap and can be near-synonyms. The variation may be stylistic rather than indicating different types of love. I've rendered both as "love" to avoid imposing a modern distinction the Greek may not support. The grief Peter experiences (v. 17) comes from being asked three times—echoing his three denials—not necessarily from a shift in vocabulary.

**"You understand" (v. 17)**: Peter shifts from οἶδας (intuitive knowledge) to γινώσκεις (experiential knowledge)—"you understand" captures both the progression and the emphasis: Jesus knows Peter's heart from direct insight.

**"Follow me" (vv. 19, 22)**: The present imperative ἀκολούθει carries the sense of continuing, ongoing action—"keep following me" or "be my follower"—but the simpler "follow me" preserves the directness and echo of the initial call.

**"Brothers" (v. 23)**: The Greek ἀδελφούς refers to the community of believers, both male and female. While the grammatical form is masculine plural (which includes mixed groups), "brothers" here functions as a community designation rather than gender-specific language.

**"We know" (v. 24)**: The shift to first-person plural indicates the Johannine community authenticating the beloved disciple's testimony. This is an editorial note from the community, not the beloved disciple's own voice.
